questions.questionText: An energy trading firm analyzes crude oil forward prices. Inventories are historically low, and the threat of supply disruptions is rising. What impact does this have on the convenience yield and forward prices?

options.text: Convenience yield rises, reducing forward prices
Convenience yield falls, increasing forward prices
Convenience yield rises, increasing forward prices
Forward prices become independent of convenience yield

questions.explanation: Scarcity increases the benefit of holding the physical asset, increasing convenience yield and reducing forward prices.

questions.questionText: A commodities arbitrageur finds that the gold forward price is significantly below the cost-of-carry fair value. However, borrowing gold in the lease market is extremely expensive. Why does this limit arbitrage?

options.text: High lease rates make shorting physical gold costly
Storage cost is negative for precious metals

questions.explanation: A reverse cash-and-carry arbitrage requires shorting gold; high lease rates eliminate profits.

questions.questionText: A natural gas marketer notices the futures curve slopes steeply downward. Storage levels are critically low, and cold weather forecasts sharply increase heating demand. What market condition is most consistent with this downward sloping curve?

options.text: Backwardation caused by high convenience yield
Contango due to high storage cost
Futures mispricing due to arbitrage limits

questions.explanation: Tight supply increases convenience yield, producing backwardation.

questions.questionText: A mining firm sells iron ore forward for delivery in six months. Shortly after locking in the price, storage costs increase unexpectedly. Which party benefits from this development?
questions.explanation: Higher storage costs raise the fair forward price; the buyer now pays less than fair value.

questions.questionText: During a drought, crop inventories fall dramatically while forward prices decline relative to spot. A commodity analyst is surprised by the price drop. Which explanation best describes this phenomenon?

options.text: Convenience yield has risen sharply due to scarcity
Storage costs have collapsed to zero

questions.explanation: Scarcity raises convenience yield and pushes forwards below spot, creating backwardation.

questions.questionText: A commodity desk evaluates an oil cash-and-carry arbitrage. The futures price is above fair value, but financing costs are high, and storage tanks are full. What is the most likely outcome?

options.text: Arbitrage is limited because storage and financing costs are too high
Convenience yield drives futures above fair value

questions.explanation: Cash-and-carry requires buying and storing physical; high storage/financing remove profits.

questions.questionText: A coffee trader evaluates futures prices across delivery months. Prices are lowest near harvest and highest months later. What best explains this seasonal pattern?

options.text: Lower inventories after harvest raise convenience yield
Interest rate seasonality drives forward curves
Exchange fees are higher during harvest season

questions.explanation: Convenience yield tends to be low at harvest and higher later, steepening the curve.

questions.questionText: A gold futures contract includes a delivery option that allows the short to choose from multiple grades of gold bars. How does this feature generally affect futures pricing?

options.text: It benefits the short and lowers the futures price
It benefits the long and raises the futures price

questions.explanation: Delivery options give value to the short, reducing the futures price relative to fair value.

questions.questionText: During extreme volatility, the spread between near-month and far-month crude futures widens sharply. Some traders believe this reflects new supply information, while others cite constraints on speculative positions. What market structure factor can cause this spread to persist even without new fundamentals?
questions.explanation: Position limits can prevent arbitrageurs from correcting price distortions across maturities.

questions.questionText: A forward on natural gas is mispriced relative to the cost-of-carry model. Storage costs are low but pipeline congestion creates a strong location basis. What makes arbitrage difficult?

options.text: Physical delivery requires access to constrained infrastructure
Futures must be held to maturity

questions.explanation: Pipeline capacity is a bottleneck; arbitrage requires physical movement of gas.

questions.questionText: A sugar producer enters a forward contract to lock in future selling prices. Later, expected crop yields rise significantly, increasing anticipated supply. What effect does this have on forward prices?

options.text: Forward prices decrease as expected supply increases
Forward prices increase due to lower convenience yield
Forward prices rise because storage costs fall
Forward prices remain unchanged due to arbitrage neutrality

questions.explanation: Higher expected supply → lower scarcity → reduced convenience yield → lower forward price.

questions.questionText: A livestock producer evaluates cattle futures, which include seasonal patterns tied to feeding costs. Feed prices spike significantly while futures prices for delivery in six months drop. What is the most likely explanation?

options.text: Convenience yield increases as feed scarcity affects short-term supply
Futures converge faster during high inflation

questions.explanation: Rising scarcity of inputs increases convenience yield, lowering futures relative to spot.

questions.questionText: Following geopolitical tensions, crude oil spot prices spike sharply. However, far-dated futures remain relatively stable. What does this divergence suggest?

options.text: Convenience yield increased sharply for near-term supply
Financing costs declined for far-dated contracts

questions.explanation: Short-term scarcity increases convenience yield near the front end, not far out.

questions.questionText: A refinery uses heating oil futures to hedge winter demand. However, basis volatility increases due to transportation bottlenecks. What risk does this create for the hedge?
questions.explanation: If physical and futures delivery points diverge, basis risk increases significantly.

questions.questionText: An aluminum producer observes that futures prices are below spot for multiple maturities. Inventories are extremely low and production outages are widespread. Which market condition best describes this environment?

options.text: Strong backwardation due to high convenience yield
Contango driven by high carry cost
Forward curve flattening due to interest rate changes

questions.explanation: Severe scarcity increases convenience yield, pushing forwards below spot.

questions.questionText: During a period of low demand, storage capacity becomes abundant. Futures prices shift into steep contango. Which factor most directly explains this transition?

options.text: Convenience yield collapses as scarcity disappears
Spot prices converge to far-dated futures

questions.explanation: When inventories are high, convenience yield is low, pushing curve into contango.

questions.questionText: A grain elevator operator enters a forward contract to sell corn after the harvest. Unexpectedly, long-term weather patterns suggest a massive crop failure several months after harvest. How might convenience yield respond in such conditions?

options.text: Convenience yield will rise due to anticipated scarcity
Convenience yield decreases because near-term supply is stable

questions.explanation: Scarcity increases the non-monetary value of physical possession.

questions.questionText: A trader analyzes the cocoa forward curve, which is currently in backwardation. Harvest is months away, and inventories across major producing countries are extremely low. Which factor most likely explains the backwardation?

options.text: High convenience yield due to scarce near-term supplies
High storage cost pushing futures lower
High interest rates reducing futures prices

questions.explanation: Backwardation typically results from high convenience yield under scarcity.

questions.questionText: An industrial metals user suspects that copper forwards are overpriced relative to the cost-of-carry model. However, borrowing copper from lenders requires significant collateral and an additional premium. Why does this limit arbitrage?

options.text: High collateral and lending premiums increase shorting costs
Convenience yield offsets all arbitrage profits
Storage costs are irrelevant for metals

questions.explanation: Shorting metals often requires collateralized borrowing; high costs prevent arbitrage.

questions.questionText: Natural gas futures for January delivery trade at a sharp premium relative to spot, while March futures trade at a discount. Seasonal demand and storage constraints both play roles. What explains the premium in January futures?

options.text: High winter demand increases convenience yield and carrying costs
Interest rates rise seasonally in winter
Storage costs decline during peak demand
Futures must be priced at fair value across all months

questions.explanation: Seasonal demand and limited storage push near-term futures higher.

questions.questionText: A trader considers a reverse cash-and-carry arbitrage in wheat futures. The forward price is significantly below fair value. However, the trader is concerned about quality differences between available physical wheat and the grade specified in the futures contract. What risk prevents arbitrage?
questions.explanation: Differences in deliverable grades create quality basis risk, limiting arbitrage.

questions.questionText: Crude oil inventories suddenly rise after several months of scarcity. The forward curve shifts from backwardation into mild contango. Which factor most directly explains the curve inversion?

options.text: Convenience yield declines as inventories increase
Futures contracts are rolled more efficiently

questions.explanation: Higher inventories reduce scarcity value, lowering convenience yield.

questions.questionText: A trader analyzing cotton forward prices notices unusually wide spreads between forward and spot prices. Transportation delays make physical delivery nearly impossible. What market factor is likely causing persistent price dislocations?
questions.explanation: Arbitrage often requires delivery; logistical bottlenecks block the arbitrage mechanism.

questions.questionText: A copper smelter uses futures to hedge future feedstock purchases. However, the smelter’s location is far from the futures delivery point, and transportation is costly. What type of risk weakens the hedge?
questions.explanation: The mismatch between futures delivery point and physical location creates location basis risk.

questions.questionText: A trader notes that gold futures prices are nearly flat across maturities. Storage costs and interest rates remain stable. What condition most likely explains the flat term structure?

options.text: Low convenience yield and stable carry costs

questions.explanation: Gold rarely has a significant convenience yield; stable carry costs produce a flat curve.

questions.questionText: Soybean futures rise sharply after reports of potential export restrictions in a major producing country. Spot prices increase less dramatically. What explains the larger move in futures prices?

options.text: Expected future scarcity increases convenience yield
Contract size distortions in futures market

questions.explanation: Expected future shortages increase convenience yield, affecting forward/futures pricing.

questions.questionText: An energy firm evaluates a calendar spread trade in natural gas futures. Winter contracts trade at a large premium to summer contracts. The trader questions whether this premium reflects fundamentals or temporary distortions. Which factor most likely justifies the winter premium?

options.text: High demand and limited storage during winter
Lower interest rates during winter months
High liquidity in winter futures contracts
Back-month contracts must be lower due to convergence

questions.explanation: Seasonal demand and limited storage capacity cause winter premiums.

questions.questionText: Aluminum forward prices fall sharply despite stable spot prices. Stockpiles at warehouses surge, and new storage facilities come online. What explains this drop in forward prices?

options.text: Convenience yield drops as inventories rise

questions.explanation: Higher inventory → lower convenience yield → lower forward prices.

questions.questionText: A trader attempts a cash-and-carry arbitrage in heating oil futures. However, funding costs spike rapidly as credit markets tighten. What is the effect on arbitrage feasibility?

options.text: Higher financing costs may eliminate arbitrage profits
Higher financing costs guarantee arbitrage profits
Spot prices converge instantly to futures prices

questions.explanation: Cash-and-carry arbitrage requires borrowing; high funding costs erase profits.

questions.questionText: A wheat farmer hedges future production using futures. However, unusual weather patterns cause regional basis volatility. What hedge risk does the farmer face?

options.text: Local basis risk due to regional price differences
Credit risk from the futures exchange

questions.explanation: Regional weather shocks can alter basis, reducing hedge effectiveness.

questions.questionText: After new mining capacity opens, iron ore inventories rise and market concerns about shortages fade. Futures prices decline relative to spot. Which factor directly contributes to this?
questions.explanation: Abundant supply lowers convenience yield, reducing forward/futures prices.

questions.questionText: An oil refiner evaluates basis between Brent and WTI futures. Pipeline issues cause a persistent price gap, preventing convergence. What risk makes hedging with one benchmark ineffective for the other?
questions.explanation: Benchmark differences create persistent basis risk between crude grades.

questions.questionText: A commodity ETF that rolls futures each month suffers persistent losses due to upward-sloping futures curves. What effect is the ETF experiencing?
questions.explanation: Rolling in contango requires buying higher-priced deferred futures, causing negative roll yield.

questions.questionText: A natural gas trader observes that spot prices have risen due to a short-term supply disruption, but futures prices for deliveries two years out remain unchanged. What does this imply?

options.text: A short-term spike in convenience yield
Arbitrage forces futures to move with spot

questions.explanation: Short-term scarcity affects front-month futures, not long-dated contracts.

questions.questionText: A gold producer enters into a forward contract to sell 10,000 ounces of gold for USD 1,200 per ounce. The one-year futures price for gold is USD 1,250. The risk-free rate is 5% per annum. What is the implied lease rate for gold?
questions.explanation: The lease rate can be calculated using: F = S₀ × e^(R - I)T. Using S₀ = 1200, F = 1250, R = 0.05, and T = 1 year, L ≈ 0.92%.

questions.questionText: The current spot price of crude oil is USD 75 per barrel. The storage cost for crude oil is USD 2 per barrel per year, and the risk-free rate is 8% per annum (compounded annually). What is the forward price of crude oil for a one-year contract?
questions.explanation: Using the cost of carry model: F = (S + U)(1 + R)^T. Where S = 75, U = 2, R = 0.08, and T = 1 year. F = (75 + 2) * (1 + 0.08) = 83.16.

questions.questionText: The spot price of copper is USD 5,000 per metric ton, and the six-month futures price is USD 5,100. The risk-free rate is 6% per annum (compounded annually). What is the implied convenience yield for copper?
questions.explanation: The convenience yield is calculated using: Y = ((S(1 + R)^T) / F)^(1/T) - 1. Using S = 5000, F = 5100, R = 0.06, T = 0.5 years, Y ≈ 1.88%.

questions.questionText: What is the difference between an American and a European option?

options.text: An American option can only be exercised at maturity, while a European option can be exercised at any time before maturity.
An American option can be exercised at any time before maturity, while a European option can only be exercised at maturity.
An American option has a fixed strike price, while a European option has a floating strike price.
There is no difference between an American and European option.

questions.explanation: An American option can be exercised at any time before the maturity date, whereas a European option can only be exercised at maturity.

questions.questionText: What is the intrinsic value of a call option?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic value of a call option is the maximum of (S - K, 0), where S is the current asset price and K is the strike price.

questions.questionText: If the price of the underlying asset is greater than the strike price, what type of option is this considered?
questions.explanation: A call option is in-the-money when the price of the underlying asset is greater than the strike price.

questions.questionText: What happens if a European call option is exercised when the asset price is below the strike price?

options.text: The trader incurs a loss equal to the strike price minus the asset price.
The trader makes a profit equal to the strike price minus the asset price.
The option is exercised at the market price.

questions.explanation: If the asset price is below the strike price, a European call option will not be exercised as it would result in a loss.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes the risk of writing a covered call?

options.text: Limited risk with unlimited profit potential.
Unlimited risk with limited profit potential.
Limited risk with limited profit potential.
Unlimited risk with unlimited profit potential.

questions.explanation: Writing a covered call involves a limited risk as the writer already owns the underlying asset, and the profit potential is also limited by the premium received from selling the call option.

questions.questionText: What is the difference between the profit and the payoff from an option?

options.text: Profit includes the cost of the option premium, while payoff does not.
Profit includes the potential payoff from the option, while payoff includes the cost of the premium.
Profit is the same as payoff.
Profit is the amount paid to purchase the option, while payoff is the total return.

questions.explanation: Profit takes into account the cost of the option premium, while payoff is the value of the option at expiration, ignoring the premium paid.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is true about American-style options?

options.text: They can be exercised at any time before the expiration date.
They can only be exercised at expiration.
They can only be exercised after the expiration date.
They can be exercised before maturity but require additional fees.

questions.explanation: American-style options can be exercised at any time before or on the expiration date.

questions.questionText: How does a stock dividend affect the strike price of an option?

options.text: The strike price is adjusted downward.
The strike price is adjusted upward.

questions.explanation: In the case of a stock dividend, the strike price is adjusted downward to maintain the equivalent value of the option position.

questions.questionText: A European call option on a stock with a strike price of USD 50 costs USD 5. The current price of the stock is USD 48. What is the intrinsic value of the option?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic value of a call option is max(current stock price - strike price, 0). Since 48 - 50 = -2, the intrinsic value is 0.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a European put option with a strike price of USD 60. The option costs USD 4, and the stock price at expiration is USD 55. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = Strike price - Option premium - Stock price at expiration. Profit = 60 - 4 - 55 = USD 1.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 80. A European call option with a strike price of USD 75 costs USD 7. What would be the profit for the holder of the call option if the stock price rises to USD 90 at expiration?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (90 - 75 - 7) = USD 8.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 100 and costs USD 10. If the stock price at expiration is USD 120, what is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (120 - 100 - 10) = USD 10.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 40. A European call option with a strike price of USD 45 costs USD 3. What is the intrinsic value of the call option if the stock price is USD 50 at expiration?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic value of a call = max(stock price - strike price, 0) = max(50 - 45, 0) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a European put option with a strike price of USD 50 for a premium of USD 5. The stock price at expiration is USD 45. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (50 - 45 - 5) = USD 0.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 100. The option premium is USD 8. If the stock price at expiration is USD 110, what is the profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (110 - 100 - 8) = USD 2.

questions.questionText: A trader sells a European call option with a strike price of USD 90 for a premium of USD 6. The stock price at expiration is USD 95. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = Premium received - (Stock price at expiration - Strike price) = 6 - (95 - 90) = USD -6.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 100. A European put option with a strike price of USD 90 costs USD 5. If the stock price at expiration is USD 85, what is the profit from the put option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (90 - 85 - 5) = USD 10.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 50 and costs USD 4. If the stock price at expiration is USD 55, what is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (55 - 50 - 4) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 40. A European call option with a strike price of USD 38 costs USD 3. What is the intrinsic value of the call option if the stock price rises to USD 45 at expiration?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic value of a call = max(stock price - strike price, 0) = max(45 - 38, 0) = USD 7.

questions.questionText: A European put option has a strike price of USD 70 and costs USD 6. The stock price at expiration is USD 65. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (70 - 65 - 6) = USD 1.

questions.questionText: A stock is priced at USD 120. A European call option with a strike price of USD 100 costs USD 12. If the stock price at expiration is USD 115, what is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (115 - 100 - 12) = USD 3.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 40. The option premium is USD 2. If the stock price at expiration is USD 35, what is the profit or loss for the holder?
questions.explanation: Since the option will not be exercised, the loss is equal to the option premium, USD -2.

questions.questionText: A stock is priced at USD 25. A European put option with a strike price of USD 30 costs USD 4. If the stock price at expiration is USD 20, what is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (30 - 20 - 4) = USD 10.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 75. The option premium is USD 5. If the stock price at expiration is USD 85, what is the profit or loss for the holder?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (85 - 75 - 5) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 50. A European call option with a strike price of USD 55 costs USD 6. If the stock price at expiration is USD 60, what is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (60 - 55 - 6) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A trader compares American and European put options with identical strike and maturity. The American put trades at a premium above the European put. What feature explains this difference?

options.text: American puts can be exercised early
European puts have negative intrinsic value
Interest rates eliminate early exercise benefits

questions.explanation: Early exercise rights add value to American puts.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager sells a put option to generate income. She believes the stock will remain stable, but unexpected market volatility emerges. What risk becomes most significant for the seller?

options.text: Large losses if the stock falls sharply

questions.explanation: Selling naked puts exposes the seller to significant downside risk.

questions.questionText: A trader considers buying a call option on a volatile technology stock. The current market is experiencing significant intraday swings, and implied volatility has risen sharply. How does an increase in implied volatility influence the call option's fair value?

options.text: It increases because higher volatility raises the option’s time value
It decreases because volatility lowers intrinsic value
It remains unchanged because volatility does not affect calls
It decreases due to increased hedge costs

questions.explanation: Higher volatility increases the probability that the option ends in-the-money, increasing time value.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager evaluates buying a deep in-the-money put option as a hedge. Interest rates are rising, and dividends for the underlying equity are expected to increase. What is the combined effect on European put prices?

options.text: Put values decrease with higher rates but increase with higher dividends
Put values increase with higher rates and dividends
Put values decrease with higher dividends but increase with higher rates
Put values remain unchanged because puts are insensitive to rates

questions.explanation: Rates reduce put values; dividends reduce call values, thus support put values.

questions.questionText: An investor holds a European call option on a stock that pays a dividend before expiration. The investor expects a large dividend increase. How will a higher dividend impact the call option price?

options.text: Call price decreases because dividends reduce expected future stock price
Call price increases because dividends raise intrinsic value
Call price remains unchanged because only volatility matters
Call price becomes equal to intrinsic value only

questions.explanation: Dividends reduce expected future stock price → lower call value.

questions.questionText: A trader computes put–call parity for a European option. However, the observed market prices violate the parity relationship, with the call appearing overpriced. Which arbitrage strategy exploits this violation?

options.text: Sell the call, buy the put, and buy the stock
Buy the call, sell the put, and short the stock
Sell both put and call options
Buy the call and buy the stock simultaneously

questions.explanation: If call is overpriced, sell call and buy synthetic call (put + stock).

questions.questionText: An investor expects moderate upward movement in a stock but wants to limit downside risk. They consider a bull call spread using two European calls with different strikes. What is the primary advantage of this strategy?

options.text: Lower premium cost compared to buying a single call
Guaranteed break-even regardless of stock movement

questions.explanation: Bull call spreads reduce cost by selling a higher-strike call.

questions.questionText: A trader examines an out-of-the-money put option with little time remaining to expiration. The option’s price is almost entirely time value. What happens to the option value as expiration approaches?

options.text: Time value decays quickly, approaching zero
Put value rises due to interest rate effects

questions.explanation: Time decay accelerates near expiration, especially for OTM options.

questions.questionText: Traders observe that implied volatility differs across strike prices, forming a volatility skew. Deep out-of-the-money puts exhibit significantly higher implied volatility. What market risk does this skew most likely reflect?

options.text: Reduced liquidity in call options only

questions.explanation: Higher IV on OTM puts indicates demand for downside hedging (crash risk).

questions.questionText: An investor holds an American call option on a dividend-paying stock. Unlike European calls, American calls can be exercised early. Under what condition might early exercise be optimal?

options.text: Just before a large dividend payment
At any time when the option is in the money

questions.explanation: Early exercise of American calls may be optimal to capture dividends.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a straddle position expecting high future volatility. Shortly before expiration, volatility collapses, and the underlying price barely moves. What is the most likely outcome?

options.text: The straddle loses most of its value
The straddle gains due to stable price
The straddle becomes delta neutral and unaffected
The straddle value increases due to lower gamma risk

questions.explanation: Straddles require high volatility; low volatility crushes option time value.

questions.questionText: A risk manager analyzes pricing of long-dated options. She notes that liquidity is lower for these maturities and bid–ask spreads are wider. What implication does this have for fair valuation?

options.text: Transaction costs and illiquidity premiums raise effective purchase price
Long-dated options always trade below intrinsic value
Interest rates fully determine long-dated option prices

questions.explanation: Wide spreads act like additional cost, elevating effective premium paid.

questions.questionText: An investor considers selling a naked call option on a highly volatile stock. What is the primary risk associated with this strategy?

options.text: Unlimited potential losses if stock price rises
Loss limited to the option premium
No market risk due to symmetry

questions.explanation: Selling naked calls has theoretically unlimited upside loss risk.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a protective put strategy in which a stock is purchased along with a put option. What benefit does this strategy provide?

options.text: Downside protection while maintaining upside potential
Free hedging with no premium cost

questions.explanation: Protective puts insure downside losses while preserving upside gains (minus premium).

questions.questionText: A call option is trading with significant time value even though it is deep in the money. Which factor most likely explains the high time value?

options.text: Long time to expiration increases option time value
Deep ITM calls have no time value

questions.explanation: Even ITM options have meaningful time value when expiration is far away.

questions.questionText: A volatility trader observes that at-the-money options trade with significantly higher implied volatility than in previous weeks. The stock’s fundamentals haven't changed much, but macroeconomic uncertainty has increased. What does rising implied volatility indicate?
questions.explanation: Higher IV reflects increased uncertainty about future price movement.

questions.questionText: A trader constructs a covered call by holding a stock and selling a call option. What is the main trade-off of this strategy?

options.text: Limited upside in exchange for receiving premium
Guaranteed profit regardless of stock movement

questions.explanation: Covered calls generate premium income but cap upside at the strike price.

questions.questionText: A trader hedges a short stock position by purchasing a call option. What is the maximum loss of this combined position?

options.text: The call premium minus any gain on the short stock
Loss is fixed at the strike price
Loss equals the intrinsic value only

questions.explanation: A long call caps upside risk of a short stock position.

questions.questionText: An option is trading far below its theoretical value suggested by put–call parity. Which condition could justify the deviation without arbitrage?
questions.explanation: Short-selling constraints can prevent arbitrage even when parity appears violated.

questions.questionText: A risk manager expects volatility to decline significantly. She considers selling an at-the-money strangle. What is the main risk associated with this strategy?

options.text: Large losses if the underlying moves sharply in either direction
Limited gains due to long volatility exposure

questions.explanation: Selling a strangle exposes the seller to large directional moves in either direction.

questions.questionText: A trader is evaluating a European call that expires in three months. Market makers have significantly widened bid–ask spreads due to uncertainty about upcoming economic announcements. How does a wider bid–ask spread affect the cost of entering a long call position?

options.text: It increases the effective cost due to higher transaction expenses
It decreases the cost by lowering the ask price
It leaves the cost unchanged because spreads do not affect buyers
It guarantees a lower execution price

questions.explanation: Wider spreads increase transaction costs, raising cost to initiate the option position.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager is comparing two call options with identical strikes and maturities. One option has much higher implied volatility than the other. What does higher implied volatility indicate about the market’s beliefs?

options.text: The market expects larger price fluctuations
The market expects stable future prices
Time value is unaffected by volatility

questions.explanation: Implied volatility reflects expected price uncertainty and affects option premiums.

questions.questionText: A trader holds an American put that is deep in the money. Interest rates have increased, and no dividends are expected before expiration. Under what condition might early exercise still be attractive?

options.text: If time value is very low and the trader prefers immediate cash
If the underlying stock becomes less liquid

questions.explanation: Deep ITM puts with minimal time value may be exercised early to lock gains.

questions.questionText: A trader constructs a long strangle by buying an out-of-the-money call and an out-of-the-money put. When is this strategy most likely to be profitable?

options.text: When the underlying experiences a very large price movement

questions.explanation: Strangles profit from large moves in either direction (large gamma exposure).

questions.questionText: A stock index option is European-style. A trader wonders whether early exercise might ever be optimal. Under what condition can early exercise be optimal for a European option?

options.text: Never; European options cannot be exercised early
When spot price exceeds strike price by a wide margin

questions.explanation: European options cannot be exercised early regardless of conditions.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a synthetic long call created through put–call parity. What position replicates a long call according to the parity relationship?
questions.explanation: Synthetic call = long stock + long put.

questions.questionText: An options trader reviews a volatility smile pattern where both deep ITM and deep OTM options exhibit higher implied volatility compared to ATM options. Which market condition is most consistent with this pattern?
questions.explanation: High IV at tails reflects fear of extreme upside or downside moves.

questions.questionText: A firm issues employee stock options that are American-style and expire in 10 years. Which factor increases the likelihood of early exercise?

options.text: Employees wishing to diversify after a large stock price increase
High volatility increases early exercise benefits
Lower interest rates encourage early exercise

questions.explanation: Employees may exercise to diversify concentrated wealth risk.

questions.questionText: A trader uses a long butterfly spread strategy. What market condition is required for the butterfly spread to be profitable?

options.text: Low volatility with the underlying near the middle strike
High volatility with large price swings

questions.explanation: Butterfly spreads profit from low volatility and minimal price movement.

questions.questionText: An index option with high time to expiration retains considerable value even when deep out of the money. Which factor primarily explains the value?

options.text: Time value increases with longer expiration
Dividends increase the option’s intrinsic value

questions.explanation: Long-dated options have high time value even if OTM.

questions.questionText: A trader observes that call options are cheap relative to put options for the same strike. What does this most likely indicate about market expectations?

options.text: Market expects early exercise of calls

questions.explanation: Expensive puts reflect demand for downside protection.

questions.questionText: An investor buys a call and simultaneously sells a put at the same strike and maturity. What position does this replicate?

options.text: A forward contract on the underlying

questions.explanation: Call – Put = Forward (from put–call parity).

questions.questionText: When the underlying asset price becomes extremely volatile, which option Greek becomes particularly important for risk management?

options.text: Gamma, because it measures curvature of delta
Rho, because interest rates become dominant

questions.explanation: High gamma means delta changes rapidly, increasing hedging complexity.

questions.questionText: A trader sells a deep in-the-money American put. What factor increases the probability that the put will be exercised early?

options.text: High interest rates and minimal time value

questions.explanation: High rates and low time value encourage early put exercise.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager expects implied volatility to fall but believes the price of the underlying will remain stable. Which option strategy benefits most from this view?
questions.explanation: Short straddles profit from low volatility and stable underlying levels.

questions.questionText: An option portfolio is delta neutral but heavily short gamma. What is the primary risk the trader faces?

options.text: Large losses if the underlying moves sharply

questions.explanation: Short gamma means losses increase rapidly with big underlying moves.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 100 and the premium is USD 8. The stock price at expiration is USD 120. What is the profit to the holder of the call option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (120 - 100 - 8) = USD 12.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a European put option with a strike price of USD 50 and a premium of USD 3. The stock price at expiration is USD 45. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (50 - 45 - 3) = USD 2.

questions.questionText: A stock is currently priced at USD 70, and a European call option with a strike price of USD 65 costs USD 6. What is the intrinsic value of the option?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic value = max(S - K, 0) = max(70 - 65, 0) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 120, and its premium is USD 15. The stock price at expiration is USD 130. What is the profit for the option holder?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (130 - 120 - 15) = USD -5 (loss). Option D refers to the magnitude of the loss (USD 5).

questions.questionText: A European put option with a strike price of USD 90 costs USD 5. The stock price at expiration is USD 85. What is the profit from the put option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (90 - 85 - 5) = USD 0 (break-even).

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 100. The current stock price is USD 95, and the premium is USD 5. What will be the intrinsic value of the option?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic value of a call option is max(current stock price - strike price, 0). Since 95 - 100 = -5, the intrinsic value is 0.

questions.questionText: A European put option with a strike price of USD 60 costs USD 8. The stock price at expiration is USD 50. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium. Profit = 60 - 50 - 8 = USD 2.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 110. The current stock price is USD 100. The premium is USD 10. What is the option's intrinsic value if the stock price at expiration is USD 120?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic value = max(stock price at expiration - strike price, 0). Since 120 - 110 = 10, the intrinsic value is USD 10.

questions.questionText: A European put option has a strike price of USD 90. The premium is USD 5. The stock price at expiration is USD 80. What is the trader's profit?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (90 - 80 - 5) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A European call option with a strike price of USD 100 has a premium of USD 12. The stock price at expiration is USD 130. What is the profit or loss from this option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (130 - 100 - 12) = USD 18.

questions.questionText: A European put option with a strike price of USD 120 costs USD 7. The stock price at expiration is USD 115. What is the profit from the option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (120 - 115 - 7) = USD -2.

questions.questionText: A stock is priced at USD 40. A European call option has a strike price of USD 35 and a premium of USD 4. What is the intrinsic value of the call option?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic value = max(stock price - strike price, 0) = max(40 - 35, 0) = USD 5.

questions.questionText: A European call option has a strike price of USD 70, and its premium is USD 6. The stock price at expiration is USD 65. What is the profit from the call option?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Stock price at expiration - Strike price - Option premium) = (65 - 70 - 6) = USD -6.

questions.questionText: A European put option has a strike price of USD 80 and the premium is USD 4. The stock price at expiration is USD 75. What is the profit or loss?
questions.explanation: Profit = (Strike price - Stock price at expiration - Option premium) = (80 - 75 - 4) = USD 1.

questions.questionText: A stock price doubles in a very short period. Which option type experiences the greatest increase in delta due to convexity?
questions.explanation: ATM options have the highest gamma, causing delta to change rapidly.

questions.questionText: A trader examines call option upper bounds. Which inequality must always hold for a European call?
questions.explanation: The call option cannot exceed the value of the underlying asset.

questions.questionText: A European put option is trading at a price lower than its theoretical minimum bound. What arbitrage opportunity becomes available?

options.text: Buy the put and short the stock, locking in riskless profit
Sell the put and buy the stock
Buy the call and sell the put

questions.explanation: If put price is too low, buy put + short stock gives arbitrage via put–call parity violation.

questions.questionText: A risk manager compares a stock position with a long call option. Which property explains why the long call exhibits convexity?

options.text: Option delta increases as the underlying rises

questions.explanation: Convexity arises because delta changes with price direction (positive gamma).

questions.questionText: Two European call options differ only in strike: K1 < K2. Which relationship must always hold?
questions.explanation: Lower strike → higher call value because option is more likely to finish in the money.

questions.questionText: A trader examines two European puts with different maturities but identical strikes. Which inequality must hold?

options.text: Longer-maturity put must be worth at least as much as the shorter one
Shorter-maturity put must always be more valuable
Both puts must have equal values
Maturity has no effect on put value

questions.explanation: Longer maturity provides more downside protection, increasing put value.

questions.questionText: A call option with positive time value is mistakenly exercised early by an investor. Which outcome results from this action?

options.text: The investor loses all remaining time value
The investor gains additional intrinsic value
The investor benefits from lower volatility
The option transforms into a forward contract

questions.explanation: Early exercise destroys time value unless dividends justify it.

questions.questionText: A European put option shows negative time value in market data. What is the most likely explanation?

options.text: Market data error, since option time value cannot be negative
High volatility creates negative time value
Stock price shocks reduce time value below zero

questions.explanation: Time value cannot be negative for European options—implies mispricing or data error.

questions.questionText: An American put option on a non-dividend-paying stock is deep in the money. Which factor makes early exercise more attractive?

options.text: Low time value compared to intrinsic value
Possibility of a large upward stock move
Higher interest rates reduce exercise benefit

questions.explanation: Minimal time value favors early exercise for deep ITM puts.

questions.questionText: A trader observes that two European call options differ only in volatility. Which relationship must hold?

options.text: Volatility has no effect on call prices
Call prices must be identical due to parity

questions.explanation: Higher volatility raises the probability of ending ITM, increasing call value.

questions.questionText: A risk manager notes that deep out-of-the-money options retain small but positive value. Which characteristic explains this?

options.text: Time value remains positive as there is still a chance of finishing ITM
Dividends increase value regardless of moneyness
Interest rates guarantee a minimum value

questions.explanation: Even far OTM options can finish ITM, giving them positive time value.

questions.questionText: Which factor directly causes American options to be more valuable than European options?

options.text: Right to exercise at any time before expiration

questions.explanation: Early exercise rights add value to American options.

questions.questionText: A trader compares two European calls with different maturities. The longer-maturity call always has at least as much value as the shorter one. Which property explains this?

options.text: More time increases optionality and upside potential
Intrinsic value must increase with maturity
Time decay is irrelevant for longer maturities

questions.explanation: Longer horizons give the option more time to become profitable.

questions.questionText: A European put option with long time to maturity retains a high premium even though the stock price is far above the strike. What property explains the premium?

options.text: Greater time horizon increases probability of finishing ITM
Intrinsic value is maximized when OTM
Interest rates force put values higher
Put options never lose value before maturity

questions.explanation: Long maturity increases optionality even for OTM puts.

questions.questionText: Which moneyness condition gives options the highest gamma exposure?
questions.explanation: Gamma peaks at ATM because small price changes have largest impact on delta.

questions.questionText: Two European puts have strikes K1 and K2, with K1 < K2. Which inequality must always hold?
questions.explanation: Higher strike → higher put value because payoff increases.

questions.questionText: A risk manager finds that an American call is priced below its intrinsic value. What does this suggest?

options.text: Arbitrage opportunity because American calls must be worth at least intrinsic value
Call is fairly priced due to interest rates

questions.explanation: American calls must be worth at least intrinsic; otherwise arbitrage exists.

questions.questionText: A risk manager notices that the time value of a call option is significantly higher than comparable options. The underlying recently entered a period of unusually high volatility. Why would this increase the option’s time value?

options.text: Higher volatility increases the probability of ending in-the-money
Higher volatility reduces the option’s intrinsic value
Higher volatility lowers the upper bound of call prices
Volatility affects intrinsic value only, not time value

questions.explanation: Time value expands with volatility because uncertainty increases potential upside.

questions.questionText: A trader observes an American call option on a dividend-paying stock. The dividend is large and is scheduled before expiration. Under which condition is early exercise optimal?

options.text: When the gain from receiving the dividend exceeds the lost time value

questions.explanation: Early call exercise may be optimal to capture dividends if time value is small.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a call option priced at exactly S − K discounted at the risk-free rate. What does this imply about the option’s time value?

options.text: The time value equals the dividend yield

questions.explanation: A call priced at intrinsic value (or PV-adjusted equivalent) has no time value.

questions.questionText: Two European calls differ only in volatility. One has implied volatility of 10% and the other 40%. What must be true about their relative values?

options.text: The 40% volatility call must be worth more
Both calls must have equal value
The 10% volatility call must be worth more
Volatility does not affect European call prices

questions.explanation: Higher volatility increases the probability of finishing ITM.

questions.questionText: A risk manager notes that an American put option is priced significantly above its European counterpart. What factor explains the difference?

options.text: American puts can be exercised early when deep in the money
European puts carry higher time value
American puts have no intrinsic value
European puts cannot be hedged effectively

questions.explanation: Early exercise is valuable when downside risk is high.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager identifies a European call that is cheaper than the corresponding synthetic call from put–call parity. What arbitrage strategy applies?

options.text: Buy the cheap call and sell the synthetic call
Short the call and buy the synthetic call
Buy both and hold to expiration
No arbitrage because parity only holds for American options

questions.explanation: If call < synthetic call, buy the undervalued instrument and short the overpriced one.

questions.questionText: A trader examines the lower bound for a European put. Which inequality must hold?

options.text: P must equal its intrinsic value

questions.explanation: The put lower bound is K discounted − S, or intrinsic value if positive.

questions.questionText: A trader compares gamma exposure across options. Which option type exhibits the largest gamma?
questions.explanation: ATM short-term options have the highest curvature of delta.

questions.questionText: An investor mistakenly believes that a call option's value decreases as volatility increases. What correction should be made?

options.text: Higher volatility increases option value because upside potential rises
Higher volatility reduces option value through time decay
Volatility reduces intrinsic value but increases time value

questions.explanation: Volatility increases the expected profit potential of a call.

questions.questionText: A trader considers a violation of monotonicity: a call option with a higher strike is priced above one with a lower strike. What is the implication?

options.text: Arbitrage exists because call prices must decrease with strike
This configuration is normal when volatility rises
Put-call parity requires higher strike calls to be more valuable
Time value is irrelevant for strike comparisons

questions.explanation: Calls must be non-increasing in strike; violation implies arbitrage.

questions.questionText: A European call option is priced at $0. Which situation makes this possible?

options.text: The option is far out-of-the-money with zero probability of finishing ITM
Intrinsic value is positive but time value is negative

questions.explanation: Only far OTM options with negligible probability can have near-zero value.

questions.questionText: Market data shows two European puts with identical strikes but different values. One trades above its theoretical upper bound. What action creates arbitrage?

options.text: Sell the overpriced put and hedge with stock and bonds
Buy the overpriced put and short the underlying
Buy both puts and hold to maturity

questions.explanation: Selling overpriced options and hedging via parity creates risk-free profit.

questions.questionText: If a call option has delta of 0.98, what can be inferred about its moneyness?
questions.explanation: Delta near 1 indicates strong ITM behavior.

questions.questionText: A trader reviews the no-arbitrage upper bound for a European call option. Which boundary condition must be satisfied?
questions.explanation: A call cannot be worth more than the underlying asset itself.

questions.questionText: A trader notes that an option has lost most of its time value and is close to expiration. How does this affect the likelihood of early exercise for an American put?

options.text: Increases likelihood if put is deep in-the-money
Has no impact on exercise decisions

questions.explanation: Low time value makes early exercise more attractive for ITM puts.

questions.questionText: A European put option’s value increases while the underlying stock price remains constant. Which factor most likely caused this?
questions.explanation: Puts benefit from higher volatility because downside potential grows.

questions.questionText: A trader constructs a bull call spread using a long call at strike 50 and a short call at strike 60. Both options expire in one month. Under which condition does the strategy produce its maximum profit?

options.text: When the stock price finishes at or above 60
When the stock price remains below 50
When the stock price finishes exactly at 55

questions.explanation: A bull call spread profits fully when both options are in-the-money but capped at the difference in strikes minus net premium.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager uses a covered call strategy by holding a stock and selling a call option. The investor expects moderate price appreciation but wants to generate income. What is the primary risk of this strategy?

options.text: The investor forfeits upside beyond the strike price
The investor faces unlimited downside risk on the call option
The strategy requires significant margin financing
The call seller loses time value as expiration approaches

questions.explanation: Covered calls sacrifice upside beyond the strike in exchange for premium income.

questions.questionText: A trader constructs a long straddle by buying an at-the-money call and put. Volatility unexpectedly collapses, and the stock price remains stable. What outcome should the trader expect?

options.text: Losses due to time decay and lower implied volatility
Large gains if the stock price stays close to the strike
Neutral outcome because one option will offset the other
Profits from the reduction in volatility

questions.explanation: Long straddles require large price movements or high volatility; otherwise both options lose time value.

questions.questionText: A trader creates a synthetic long forward by buying a call and selling a put at the same strike and maturity. What market view does this strategy express?

options.text: Bullish view on the underlying asset
Neutral view that volatility will fall
View that interest rates will drop before expiration

questions.explanation: Long call + short put replicates a long forward, which profits when price rises.

questions.questionText: An investor constructs a protective put by buying stock and purchasing a put option. The investor wants downside protection while retaining upside potential. What is the main drawback of this strategy?

options.text: The cost of the put reduces overall portfolio return
Upside is capped at the strike
The put must be exercised early to capture gains
The strategy increases delta exposure significantly

questions.explanation: Protective puts cost money, lowering expected returns.

questions.questionText: A call spread is constructed with a long call at strike 100 and a short call at strike 120. How does increasing volatility affect the value of the call spread?

options.text: Its value increases because long-call gamma exceeds short-call gamma
Its value decreases because both options lose time value
It is unaffected by volatility changes
It becomes worthless as volatility increases

questions.explanation: Lower-strike long call is more sensitive to volatility than the higher-strike short call.

questions.questionText: A trader sells a naked call because she believes the underlying asset will remain stable or decline. What is the primary risk of this strategy?

options.text: Limited losses up to the strike
Delta decreases rapidly with price declines

questions.explanation: Short calls without coverage expose the seller to unlimited loss if prices rise sharply.

questions.questionText: An options trader constructs a collar by holding a long stock position, buying a put, and selling a call. What does this strategy do?

options.text: Limits both downside risk and upside potential

questions.explanation: Collars protect against downside but cap upside by selling a call.

questions.questionText: A trader expects volatility to increase significantly but does not want directional risk. Which strategy best exploits this expectation?
questions.explanation: Long straddles profit from large moves or rising volatility regardless of direction.

questions.questionText: A long iron condor is constructed with two credit spreads: a call spread and a put spread. What condition results in maximum profit?

options.text: Underlying price stays within the inner strikes
Underlying price moves far above the upper strike
Underlying price collapses below the lowest strike

questions.explanation: Iron condors profit when price stays in a range and both spreads expire worthless.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a vertical put spread: long put at 80 and short put at 70. The underlying declines to 60 at expiration. What happens?

options.text: The spread pays its maximum value of 10
The trader loses the entire premium
Only the short put finishes in-the-money

questions.explanation: Both puts finish ITM with 10 difference in strikes, yielding max payoff.

questions.questionText: A trader sells a straddle expecting low volatility. However, unexpected economic news causes a sudden price jump. What happens to the short straddle?

options.text: It experiences large losses because both options become valuable
It profits because theta offsets gamma risk
It breaks even because one option offsets the other
It becomes risk-free if the jump is temporary

questions.explanation: Short straddles lose heavily when price moves sharply up or down.

questions.questionText: An investor constructs a long calendar spread by buying a long-dated call and selling a short-dated call at the same strike. When is this strategy most profitable?

options.text: When the underlying stays near the strike until the short-dated option expires
When the underlying moves dramatically in either direction
When interest rates cause the long-dated option to expire early

questions.explanation: Calendar spreads profit when short-term options decay faster than long-term options.

questions.questionText: A trader executes a ratio spread by buying one call and selling two calls at a higher strike. What is the main risk of this position?

options.text: Significant upside risk if the underlying rises sharply
Losses occur only if volatility falls
The position always has limited risk

questions.explanation: Selling more calls than purchased creates large upside risk.

questions.questionText: A delta-neutral strategy is constructed with long gamma. What is the key characteristic of this position?

options.text: It gains from volatility because gamma is positive
It always loses value due to theta
It is unaffected by jumps in the underlying price

questions.explanation: Positive gamma benefits from price swings even when directionless.

questions.questionText: An investor uses a long strangle composed of an OTM call and OTM put. Compared to a long straddle, the strangle has which characteristic?

options.text: Lower cost but requires larger price movement to profit
Higher cost and smaller break-even range
Lower cost and smaller movement needed to profit
Identical payoff profile but opposite volatility exposure

questions.explanation: Strangles cost less than straddles but need bigger moves to offset the lower deltas.

questions.questionText: A trader constructs a box spread using a bull call spread and a bear put spread at the same strikes. What does this strategy effectively create?
questions.explanation: Box spreads lock in risk-free payoff equal to the strike difference discounted at the risk-free rate.

questions.questionText: A trader is analyzing a long butterfly spread constructed entirely with call options. The strikes are 90, 100, and 110. The trader wants limited risk but also low cost. Which market outlook best fits a butterfly strategy?

options.text: The underlying will stay near the middle strike at expiration
The underlying will move sharply up or down
The underlying will trend upward consistently

questions.explanation: Butterfly spreads profit when the price ends near the middle strike due to symmetric structure.

questions.questionText: An investor sells a strangle because they anticipate that volatility will decrease and that the underlying price will remain stable. What is the main risk of a short strangle?

options.text: Large losses if the underlying moves sharply in either direction
Loss of premium if volatility rises
Losses limited to the premium paid

questions.explanation: Short strangles have unlimited upside risk and significant downside risk.

questions.questionText: A trader uses delta hedging by buying shares to offset a short call option position. Over time, the hedge requires frequent adjustments. What primarily causes the need for rebalancing?

options.text: Gamma changes delta as the underlying moves
Theta decay reduces the underlying stock price
Vega drops as interest rates fall
Delta is constant for call options

questions.explanation: Gamma measures curvature and causes delta to change, requiring hedge rebalancing.

questions.questionText: An investor constructs a reverse collar (short put, long call) expecting a strong rally. Which feature of this strategy differentiates it from a simple long call?

options.text: It generates premium income from the short put, reducing net cost
It increases gamma during falling markets
It sacrifices upside potential relative to a long call

questions.explanation: Short put reduces cost but introduces downside risk.

questions.questionText: A trader enters a long condor strategy by buying calls at strikes 90 and 120 and selling calls at 100 and 110. Compared to a butterfly, how does a condor differ?

options.text: Condors have a wider profit zone but lower maximum profit
Condors require fewer options to construct
Condors provide higher returns with greater risk
Condors profit only when the underlying moves sharply

questions.explanation: Condors widen the center region but reduce the max potential payoff.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a call ratio spread: long one call at 50, short two calls at 60. The underlying rises to 65. What is the main outcome?

options.text: The strategy likely incurs losses due to the extra short call
The strategy yields maximum profit at 60
The strategy breaks even because one call gains and two lose

questions.explanation: Ratio spreads lose money when the underlying moves too far in the direction of the short options.

questions.questionText: An investor buys an out-of-the-money call and an out-of-the-money put to form a strangle. Volatility increases significantly while the spot price remains unchanged. What happens to the value of the strangle?

options.text: It increases because vega is positive for both legs
It decreases because theta overwhelms vega
It collapses to zero because there was no price movement

questions.explanation: Strangles have long volatility exposure through both legs.

questions.questionText: A trader enters a long box spread. Over time, interest rates change. How does this affect the value of the box spread if markets remain arbitrage-free?

options.text: Its value remains equal to the risk-free present value of the strike difference
Its value becomes sensitive to gamma
Its value fluctuates with the underlying asset price

questions.explanation: Box spreads replicate a risk-free bond independent of volatility or delta.

questions.questionText: An options trader constructs a synthetic short forward by selling a call and buying a put at the same strike. What risk profile does this replicate?

options.text: Linear downside gains and linear upside losses
Convex payoff with respect to price increases

questions.explanation: Short forward payoff decreases linearly as prices rise.

questions.questionText: A protective put strategy is used during high volatility. How does volatility affect the cost of the hedge?

options.text: The hedge becomes more expensive because puts have positive vega
The hedge becomes cheaper as market uncertainty decreases
Volatility has no effect on protective put pricing
High volatility makes protective puts worthless

questions.explanation: Higher volatility increases option premiums, especially for puts.

questions.questionText: A bull put spread is created with a short put at strike 80 and a long put at strike 70. Which market condition leads to maximum profit?
questions.explanation: Bull put spreads profit when both puts expire worthless.

questions.questionText: A trader uses a gamma scalping strategy to profit from short-term volatility. The position is initially delta-neutral. How are profits typically generated?

options.text: By buying low and selling high when rebalancing the hedge
By collecting theta decay each day
By selling volatility at high levels

questions.explanation: Gamma scalping profits from repeated rebalancing around price fluctuations.

questions.questionText: A short calendar spread (short long-term option, long short-term option) is used when the trader expects volatility to decrease. Why?

options.text: Long-term options lose value faster when volatility falls
Short-term options always lose value faster
Calendar spreads are unaffected by volatility
Time decay increases the value of long-dated options

questions.explanation: Vega of long-dated options is larger; falling volatility hurts them more.

questions.questionText: A trader sells a put and buys a call at the same strike, forming a synthetic long forward. What additional Greek exposure is introduced that differs from holding a true forward contract?
questions.explanation: Synthetic forwards created with options have volatility exposure unlike actual forwards.

questions.questionText: A trader implements a long calendar call spread expecting moderate movement and rising volatility. What is the ideal underlying movement pattern?

options.text: The price stays near the strike until the short-term option expires
The price swings dramatically in both directions

questions.explanation: Calendar spreads profit most when the underlying stays near strike and short-term option decays faster.

questions.questionText: A trader uses a short iron butterfly (short ATM call, short ATM put, long wings). Which market environment is most risky?

options.text: A large price move in either direction
A narrow trading range around the strike

questions.explanation: Short iron butterflies suffer when volatility expands or price moves outside the wings.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a deep ITM call instead of buying the underlying to replicate a leveraged long position. What is the main advantage?

options.text: Lower capital requirement due to the option premium being smaller than underlying cost
Reduced delta exposure relative to the stock

questions.explanation: Deep ITM calls can replicate the underlying with less capital outlay.

questions.questionText: An investor implements a short call spread (short call at 70, long call at 80). Compared to a naked short call, what risk is reduced?
questions.explanation: The long call limits losses when price rises above the higher strike.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a down-and-out call option with a barrier at 70. The underlying currently trades at 72, and volatility is high. Why does an increase in volatility decrease the option’s value?

options.text: Higher volatility raises the chance of breaching the barrier
Higher volatility makes the option behave like a digital option

questions.explanation: Knock-out options lose value when volatility rises because it increases barrier-hit probability.

questions.questionText: An Asian option based on the arithmetic average is priced significantly higher than one using a geometric average. What explains this pricing difference?

options.text: Arithmetic averaging preserves more volatility than geometric averaging
Geometric averages always exceed arithmetic averages
Arithmetic averages eliminate volatility risk entirely
Geometric options are more sensitive to gamma

questions.explanation: Arithmetic averages have higher variance than geometric averages, raising option value.

questions.questionText: A digital option pays $10,000 if the underlying price exceeds 150 and zero otherwise. How does time to maturity affect its price?

options.text: More time increases the probability of finishing in-the-money
Time has no effect because payoff is fixed
More time decreases value because theta is positive
More time reduces its gamma exposure

questions.explanation: Digital options rely heavily on probability of finishing above the strike, which increases with time.

questions.questionText: A trader analyzes an up-and-in put option that becomes active only if the price rises above a barrier. Which pricing property makes this option particularly sensitive?

options.text: It has negative vega when the barrier is close to the current price
It has unlimited upside but limited downside
It is always more expensive than a vanilla put
It has no sensitivity to path dependence

questions.explanation: Knock-in options may decrease in value when volatility increases if activation becomes less likely.

questions.questionText: A lookback put option pays based on the maximum price the asset reached during its life. What environment increases its value?

options.text: High volatility because larger price swings increase maximum price
Low volatility because the price path becomes smoother

questions.explanation: Lookback puts benefit when the underlying had a high peak earlier.

questions.questionText: An investor buys a one-touch call option that pays $50,000 immediately if the price hits 200. What differentiates its valuation from standard barrier options?

options.text: Payoff occurs immediately upon barrier hit, not at expiration
It behaves exactly like a vanilla digital call
It has no exposure to volatility
It cannot be hedged with vanilla options

questions.explanation: One-touch options pay instantly rather than at maturity.

questions.questionText: A no-touch option pays a fixed amount if the underlying never hits a barrier. How does an increase in volatility affect its price?

options.text: Price decreases because volatility increases barrier-touch probability
Price increases because volatility boosts expected payoff

questions.explanation: Higher volatility increases probability of hitting the barrier, reducing no-touch value.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a Bermudan option, exercisable on multiple specific dates before expiration. How does its value compare to European and American options?

options.text: Value lies between European and American options
Always equal to a European option
Always equal to an American option
Always worth more than American options

questions.explanation: More exercise opportunities than European, fewer than American.

questions.questionText: Why do corridor options—options that pay based on how long the underlying stays within a price range—become more valuable in low-volatility conditions?

options.text: The underlying is more likely to remain within the corridor
Corridor options require price spikes to pay out
Corridor payoffs increase only with high volatility

questions.explanation: Low volatility increases time spent inside the corridor.

questions.questionText: A trader values a floating-strike lookback call. Unlike standard lookbacks, its strike is set at the minimum price during the option’s life. What is a key implication?

options.text: The option guarantees positive intrinsic value unless price strictly falls
The strike is fixed at inception

questions.explanation: Floating-strike lookbacks embed optimal strike selection.

questions.questionText: Which feature causes a binary option to have significant gamma exposure near the strike?

options.text: Small price movements drastically alter the probability of finishing ITM
Gamma is always zero for digital options
Expiry value changes linearly with the underlying
Probability of exercise is fixed at 50%

questions.explanation: Digital options have sharp probability transitions around the strike.

questions.questionText: A barrier option is knocked out if touched even for an instant. Which variant requires the price to stay beyond a barrier for a minimum time before knock-out?
questions.explanation: Parisian barriers depend on time spent beyond the barrier, not just touching it.

questions.questionText: Why might a quanto option be preferred over a standard foreign option?

options.text: It removes currency conversion volatility from the payoff
It eliminates exposure to the underlying price entirely

questions.explanation: Quantos protect investors from currency risk by fixing the FX rate for payoff conversion.

questions.questionText: A compound option provides the right to buy or sell another option at a future date. Which scenario increases the compound option’s value?

options.text: High volatility in the underlying and long time to maturity
Absence of time value in the underlying option
When the underlying option is deep OTM with no chance of recovery

questions.explanation: Compound options benefit from volatility and optionality in the underlying option itself.

questions.questionText: Which exotic instrument resembles a forward contract but pays the average price instead of the terminal price?
questions.explanation: Asian forwards replace terminal price with an arithmetic average.

questions.questionText: A chooser option allows the holder to select call or put at a decision date. What market condition increases its value?

options.text: High volatility, because the final choice benefits from large movements
Low volatility, because the direction is predictable
Only when dividends are extremely high

questions.explanation: Choose-later optionality gains value as volatility rises.

questions.questionText: Why does a lookback call option have higher vega than a vanilla call?

options.text: Volatility increases the likelihood of a lower historical minimum price
Lookbacks are not affected by pricing path
Lookbacks are insensitive to drift and volatility

questions.explanation: Higher volatility creates more opportunities for extreme path values.

questions.questionText: Why is a zero-strike call often viewed as equivalent to a forward contract?

options.text: Its payoff at expiration equals the underlying price
It guarantees a fixed payoff irrespective of price

questions.explanation: A zero-strike call replicates a long forward payoff.

questions.questionText: A knock-out barrier call option ceases to exist if the underlying ever falls below 80. The option is initially worth significantly less than a vanilla call with the same strike and maturity. Why?

options.text: There is a probability the option will be extinguished before expiration
Barrier features always increase option value
Knock-out options guarantee positive payoff if the barrier is reached

questions.explanation: Knock-out barriers reduce value because the option becomes worthless if the barrier is touched.

questions.questionText: A trader examines a knock-in put option that becomes active only if the underlying hits 50. The current price is 95, and volatility is low. How does this affect the option’s price?

options.text: The option is cheap because the activation event is unlikely
The option is expensive because knock-in options carry additional intrinsic value
The option’s price equals that of a vanilla put
The option must be worthless under these conditions

questions.explanation: Low volatility reduces probability of hitting the barrier, making knock-in options cheaper.

questions.questionText: An Asian call option’s payoff depends on the average price of the underlying over the last 60 days. When compared to a vanilla call, what characteristic typically lowers the Asian option’s price?

options.text: Averaging reduces volatility of the underlying price path
Averaging results in higher gamma exposures

questions.explanation: Averaging smooths price movements, reducing effective volatility and lowering option value.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates a digital cash-or-nothing call option. The payoff is fixed at $1,000 if the underlying finishes above 120 at expiration. Which factor most influences the option’s value?

options.text: The risk-neutral probability of finishing above the strike
The magnitude of price movement above the strike
Convexity of the payoff beyond the strike
