questions.explanation: Digital options depend solely on the probability of the underlying exceeding the barrier.

questions.questionText: A lookback call option allows the holder to buy at the minimum price over the option’s life. Why is this option significantly more expensive than a vanilla call?

options.text: It guarantees optimal historical exercise price
Lookbacks have lower volatility exposure than vanilla calls

questions.explanation: Lookback payoffs embed the maximum advantage over the historical price path.

questions.questionText: A chooser option lets the holder decide at a future date whether the option becomes a call or a put. Why is this feature valuable?

options.text: It allows the holder to wait for market direction before deciding
It prevents losses regardless of market movement
It always results in a higher payoff than both plain vanilla options
It reduces exposure to volatility entirely

questions.explanation: The flexibility to choose increases option value due to embedded optionality.

questions.questionText: Barrier options are path dependent. How does this path dependence typically affect their valuation?

options.text: It reduces the option’s value because knockout risk lowers expected payoff
It increases value because the path provides additional payoff opportunities
It converts the option into a synthetic forward

questions.explanation: Barrier features generally reduce value by creating forfeiture risk.

questions.questionText: A double-barrier option knocks out if the price hits either an upper or lower barrier. How does this structure compare to a single-barrier option?

options.text: Double-barrier options are cheaper because they have a higher chance of knockout
Double-barrier options are more expensive because they offer double protection
Double-barrier options and single-barrier options always have identical value
Double-barrier options eliminate volatility risk entirely

questions.explanation: More barriers increase the probability of invalidation, lowering value.

questions.questionText: An Asian geometric average option trades at a discount relative to an arithmetic average Asian option. What explains the price difference?

options.text: Geometric averages have lower variance than arithmetic averages
Geometric averages always exceed arithmetic averages
Geometric options have higher gamma exposure

questions.explanation: Geometric averaging reduces volatility and therefore reduces option value.

questions.questionText: A digital asset-or-nothing call pays the underlying’s value if the price exceeds 100 at expiration. What does this imply about risk exposure?

options.text: The option’s payoff is nonlinear and depends on both probability and asset level
The payoff is independent of underlying value
The option has lower exposure to volatility than a vanilla call
The payoff forms a linear function of price

questions.explanation: Asset-or-nothing options are sensitive to both price probability and magnitude.

questions.questionText: A barrier option’s value increases when volatility decreases. Which type of barrier option most likely exhibits this behavior?
questions.explanation: Lower volatility reduces the probability the barrier is hit; this increases knock-in value.

questions.questionText: A compound call-on-call option grants the right to purchase a call option at a future date. What market view justifies buying such an option?

options.text: Uncertainty about volatility but belief that option prices may rise
Expectation that volatility will remain extremely stable
Need for immediate exposure to directional movement
Desire to gain linear payoff relative to underlying

questions.explanation: Compound options provide leveraged exposure to option price movement.

questions.questionText: A trader uses a Parisian barrier option, which considers how long the underlying remains beyond a barrier rather than whether it simply touches it. What effect does this modification have?

options.text: Reduces sensitivity to brief, temporary price spikes
Guarantees higher value than a regular barrier option
Makes the option insensitive to volatility

questions.explanation: Parisian barriers require sustained movement, reducing impact of transitory price noise.

questions.questionText: A forward-start option begins with no defined strike; the strike is set at a future date based on market conditions. Why might firms grant these to employees?

options.text: They align employee incentives with future market performance
They eliminate volatility risk for the employer
They guarantee the employee immediate profit
They restrict employees from benefiting from stock appreciation

questions.explanation: Forward-starts make the strike contingent on future price, aligning incentives with long-term performance.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a shout option, which allows the holder to lock in gains at a chosen point before expiration. What does this embedded feature resemble?

options.text: A standard American call option structure

questions.explanation: Shout options allow gain capture without terminating the option, similar to partial exercise.

questions.questionText: A rainbow option depends on the best or worst performing asset among several underlyings. What is a key driver of the option’s value?
questions.explanation: Correlation strongly influences the probability that one asset significantly outperforms others.

questions.questionText: A zero-strike call option (ZSC) pays the underlying price at expiration. How does its risk exposure compare to owning the underlying asset?

options.text: It mimics a fully leveraged position on the underlying

questions.explanation: A ZSC replicates a forward-like linear payoff equal to the underlying price.

questions.questionText: A trader analyzes a quanto option, which pays off in a foreign currency but references an underlying asset in another currency. What unique risk does this structure hedge?

options.text: Cross-currency risk that would otherwise affect payoff translation
Volatility changes in both domestic and foreign markets

questions.explanation: Quanto features eliminate currency conversion volatility for the payoff.

questions.questionText: A 2-year zero-coupon yield rises from 3.0% to 3.4% while the 10-year yield remains unchanged. What most likely caused this shift in the yield curve?
questions.explanation: A rise in short-maturity yields with long maturities unchanged suggests revised expectations for near-term monetary policy.

questions.questionText: A fixed-income analyst notes that yield curves are usually quoted with annual compounding, but discount factors often use continuous compounding. What is the main advantage of continuous compounding?

options.text: It simplifies mathematical manipulation of rates
It always produces higher present values
It removes the need to estimate forward rates

questions.explanation: Continuous compounding yields simpler expressions for discount factors, forwards, and derivatives pricing.

questions.questionText: When interest rates rise, bond prices fall. What property of the price–yield relationship explains why price increases are smaller when yields fall than price decreases when yields rise by the same amount?
questions.explanation: Convexity makes the price-yield curve curve upward, causing asymmetric price changes around yield moves.

questions.questionText: An upward-sloping yield curve most commonly reflects which underlying market expectation?

options.text: Future short-term interest rates will rise
Future short-term interest rates will fall
The term premium is strictly negative

questions.explanation: Upward slopes usually indicate rising forward rates and expectations of higher future short-term rates.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager compares spot rates and forward rates. Spot rates for increasing maturities are higher than the short-term rates implied by forward curves. What does this typically imply?

options.text: Forward rates embed expectations plus risk premia
Spot rates are always unbiased predictors of future rates
Forward rates must equal future realized rates
Spot rates are unaffected by term premia

questions.explanation: Forward rates incorporate expectations for future rates plus risk compensation.

questions.questionText: A newly issued 5-year government bond has a yield of 4.1% while a 5-year zero-coupon bond has a yield of 3.7%. What explains the difference?

options.text: Zero-coupon bonds have higher liquidity premiums

questions.explanation: Coupon-paying bonds expose investors to reinvestment risk, causing yield differences versus zero-coupon bonds.

questions.questionText: When using continuous compounding, the discount factor for maturity T is exp(−rT). Which property makes this representation appealing for pricing fixed-income derivatives?

options.text: It is multiplicative across time periods

questions.explanation: Continuously compounded discounting enables clean exponential properties useful in arbitrage models.

questions.questionText: A trader observes a yield curve inversion, with 2-year yields higher than 10-year yields. What market condition is most consistent with this shape?

options.text: Higher term premia at long maturities

questions.explanation: Yield curve inversion typically reflects expectations that future short-term rates will fall.

questions.questionText: Which property of forward rates ensures that they can be derived from spot rates without arbitrage?

options.text: Spot rate compounding must match discount factor construction
Forward rates are independent of spot rates
Forward rates always exceed spot rates

questions.explanation: Arbitrage-free pricing relates spot and forward rates through consistent discount factors.

questions.questionText: The instantaneous forward rate curve slopes upward. What does this imply for discount factors?

options.text: Discount factors decline more steeply for longer maturities
Discount factors remain constant across maturities
Discount factors are unrelated to the forward curve

questions.explanation: Higher forward rates imply faster discounting for longer terms.

questions.questionText: A 6-month LIBOR rate is quoted with simple interest, while a continuously compounded yield is needed for pricing a derivative. What is the proper approach?

options.text: Convert the simple rate into a continuous rate before discounting
Ignore compounding differences if tenor < 1 year
Discount with the derivative’s expected payoff instead of the rate

questions.explanation: Consistent compounding is essential for arbitrage-free pricing.

questions.questionText: A bond trades at a premium to par. Which statement best describes its yield relative to its coupon?

options.text: Yield to maturity is lower than the coupon rate
Yield to maturity equals the coupon rate
Yield to maturity must exceed the coupon rate
Yield to maturity is unrelated to coupon rate

questions.explanation: Premium bonds have yields below their coupon rate.

questions.questionText: Bond convexity increases with maturity. What is a direct implication for long-maturity zero-coupon bonds?

options.text: They are highly sensitive to interest-rate changes
They are less volatile than coupon bonds

questions.explanation: Zero-coupon bonds have the highest duration and convexity for a given maturity.

questions.questionText: What does the pure expectations theory claim about forward rates?

options.text: They equal expected future short-term interest rates
They always include positive term premia
They are unrelated to spot rates
They incorporate inflation only, not real rates

questions.explanation: Under pure expectations, forwards are unbiased predictors of future short rates.

questions.questionText: If the yield curve is flat, which relationship between discount factors holds?

options.text: Discount factors decline exponentially with maturity
Discount factors remain constant across maturities

questions.explanation: Even with a flat curve, discounting compounds exponentially across time.

questions.questionText: A 3-year bond’s yield increases by 20 bps. Due to convexity, the actual price change differs from the duration-only approximation. How?

options.text: Actual price falls slightly less than duration predicts
Actual price falls much more than duration predicts

questions.explanation: Positive convexity cushions price declines when yields rise.

questions.questionText: A money market instrument is quoted on a discount rate basis rather than a yield basis. What is a key limitation of discount rate quoting?

options.text: It understates true yield because discount is taken off face value
It overstates yield by ignoring compounding
It cannot be used for Treasury bills
It is equivalent to continuously compounded yields

questions.explanation: Discount quoting reduces price relative to face value, understating investor yield.

questions.questionText: An analyst decomposes the yield of a long-term bond into expected short-rate averages plus a term premium. Which factor most likely increases the term premium?

options.text: Higher uncertainty about future rate paths

questions.explanation: Term premia compensate investors for interest-rate uncertainty across long horizons.

questions.questionText: When yields on short-maturity bonds rise sharply while long-term yields rise modestly, the yield curve becomes steeper at the front end. Which macroeconomic development most likely explains this behavior?

options.text: Expectations of tighter near-term monetary policy
A reduction in term premia on long bonds
A sudden collapse in credit spreads

questions.explanation: Steepening at the short end often reflects anticipated rate hikes.

questions.questionText: A trader notes that the difference between 10-year yields and 2-year yields has turned negative for several weeks. What risk should banks especially consider in such an environment?
questions.explanation: An inverted curve erodes bank profitability by compressing margins.

questions.questionText: A newly issued 10-year bond trades at par. Soon after issuance, yields on similar bonds fall. What effect does this yield decline have on the bond?

options.text: Its market price rises above par
Its market price falls below par
It becomes insensitive to interest rate changes

questions.explanation: Bond prices move inversely to yields.

questions.questionText: A bond trader decomposes a 5-year yield into an average expected short rate and a term premium. If macroeconomic uncertainty rises sharply, what happens to the term premium?

options.text: It increases to compensate for uncertainty

questions.explanation: Term premia rise with uncertainty about future yields.

questions.questionText: Short-term interest rates are quoted using simple interest conventions, while long-term rates often use semiannual compounding. What risk arises from ignoring compounding differences?

options.text: Mispricing due to inconsistent discount factors

questions.explanation: Consistent compounding prevents arbitrage and ensures coherent yield curve construction.

questions.questionText: A fixed-income investor evaluates discount factors derived from spot rates. Which property must always hold for discount factors in a positive interest rate environment?

options.text: They must decline as maturity increases
They must equal one for all maturities
They must converge to zero at all maturities below one year

questions.explanation: Positive interest rates imply that future cash flows are discounted more heavily as time increases.

questions.questionText: A 3-year zero-coupon bond has a yield of 4.0%, and a 4-year zero has a yield of 4.1%. What does this indicate about forward rates between years three and four?
questions.explanation: When spot rates rise with maturity, forward rates must exceed the longest spot rate.

questions.questionText: A bond’s yield increases by the same amount for three different maturities. For which maturity does this produce the largest price decline?
questions.explanation: Longer maturities have higher duration and price sensitivity to yield changes.

questions.questionText: A yield curve shifts upward by 30 basis points across all maturities. What type of yield curve movement is this?
questions.explanation: Parallel shifts occur when all maturities experience identical changes in yield.

questions.questionText: Under the expectations hypothesis, what does a downward sloping forward curve imply about future spot rates?

options.text: Future spot rates are expected to decline
Future spot rates are expected to rise
Forward rates reflect only liquidity premiums

questions.explanation: A downward forward curve signals falling expected future short-term rates.

questions.questionText: If the yield curve is flat but forward rates rise with maturity, what explains the difference?

options.text: Forward rates include term premia while spot rates are averages
Forward rates must be lower than spot rates
Spot rates increase faster than forward rates
Flat curves require zero term premia

questions.explanation: Spot rates average expected future rates, while forwards incorporate risk premia directly.

questions.questionText: A money market trader converts an annual compounding yield into continuous compounding. Which transformation property must be maintained?
questions.explanation: Rate conversions must preserve the same discount factor for consistency.

questions.questionText: Which scenario causes a butterfly shift in the yield curve?

options.text: Short and long rates move up while intermediate rates fall
All points on the curve move up equally
Short rates rise and long rates fall

questions.explanation: Butterfly shifts reflect curvature changes—middle maturities moving differently from wings.

questions.questionText: A government bond has very low convexity. What does this imply about its maturity and coupon structure?

options.text: It likely has a short maturity and high coupon
It likely has a long maturity and zero coupon

questions.explanation: Lower convexity corresponds to short-term, high-coupon bonds.

questions.questionText: A 1-year zero-coupon bond has a 3.5% yield, while a 2-year zero has 4.0%. Which statement is true regarding the 1-year forward rate starting in one year?
questions.explanation: Upward-sloping spot rates imply even steeper implied forward rates.

questions.questionText: When investors demand additional compensation for holding long-maturity bonds due to inflation uncertainty, what happens to the term structure?

options.text: Long-term yields rise relative to short-term yields

questions.explanation: Greater uncertainty increases term premia at long maturities.

questions.questionText: A bond's price-yield curve is convex. What does convexity guarantee about pricing errors when using only duration?

options.text: Duration-only estimates understate losses when yields rise
Duration-only estimates overstate losses when yields rise
Convexity has no influence on duration-based errors

questions.explanation: Convexity cushions price declines, so duration overestimates losses.

questions.questionText: A bond's Macaulay duration is 7 years. What must be true about the bond's modified duration?

options.text: It is slightly lower than the Macaulay duration
It is unrelated to yield changes

questions.explanation: Modified duration = Macaulay duration / (1 + yield).

questions.questionText: A corporate bond trades at a spread of 140 bps above Treasury yields. After a deterioration in the issuer’s credit outlook, the spread widens to 210 bps. What is the most direct implication for the bond’s market price?

options.text: Its price decreases due to higher required yield
Its price increases to reflect greater demand
Its price becomes less sensitive to interest rates

questions.explanation: Spread widening reflects higher credit risk, lowering the bond’s price.

questions.questionText: Two bonds have identical maturities and coupon rates, but Bond A is senior unsecured while Bond B is subordinated. In the event of issuer default, what is the most likely difference in outcomes?

options.text: Bond A will have a higher recovery rate
Bond B will have a higher recovery rate
Both will have identical recovery rates
Bond B will default less frequently

questions.explanation: Higher seniority leads to higher priority in claims and thus higher recoveries.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond issuer experiences multiple credit rating downgrades. Despite the deteriorating ratings, its bond yields remain relatively stable. Which factor most likely explains this?

options.text: The downgrades were anticipated and already priced in
Corporate bond yields are unaffected by credit risk
Bond markets ignore rating agency guidance

questions.explanation: Market-implied credit risk often moves before formal ratings do, incorporating expected downgrades early.

questions.questionText: A BBB-rated issuer offers a 7-year bond with a call option that allows early redemption at par after year three. How does the call feature affect investor risk?

options.text: Investors face reinvestment risk if the issuer calls during low-rate environments
Investors benefit from guaranteed higher yields
Interest rate volatility has no effect on call probability
Investors receive higher recovery rates during default

questions.explanation: Call features favor issuers and expose investors to reinvestment risk when rates fall.

questions.questionText: A high-yield bond trades at a significantly wider spread than a similarly rated bond from another sector. Which factor most likely explains the difference?
questions.explanation: Sector conditions strongly influence credit spreads because some industries face higher cyclical or structural risks.

questions.questionText: Two corporate bonds have identical credit ratings, maturities, and coupons. Bond X trades with a 40 bps liquidity premium relative to Bond Y. What is the most likely cause?

options.text: Bond X trades less frequently and has lower market depth
Bond X has a higher recovery rate
Bond Y has worse covenant protection
Bond Y is subordinated to Bond X

questions.explanation: Liquidity premiums compensate investors for difficulty trading certain bonds efficiently.

questions.questionText: A corporate issuer announces a leveraged buyout (LBO). Its outstanding bonds immediately trade down in price. Which factor best explains this reaction?

options.text: Financial leverage increases default risk, raising credit spreads
LBOs boost equity value and reduce bond risk
Leverage decreases probability of covenant breach

questions.explanation: LBOs increase leverage, worsening credit quality and widening spreads.

questions.questionText: When calculating the credit spread of a corporate bond, which benchmark is most commonly used?

options.text: Sovereign bond yields from emerging markets

questions.explanation: Corporate bond spreads are typically measured relative to Treasury yields.

questions.questionText: A bond investor analyzes a company's financial statements and notes declining EBITDA, increasing leverage, and weakening free cash flow. What impact is this likely to have on the issuer’s credit spread?

options.text: Credit spreads will widen as credit quality deteriorates
Credit spreads will tighten due to improved liquidity
Spreads remain unchanged because spreads only reflect market rates
Spreads decline due to lower default probability

questions.explanation: Weakening fundamentals increase perceived default risk, widening credit spreads.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond includes a covenant limiting additional borrowing. Why is this covenant valuable to bondholders?

options.text: It restricts leverage, reducing default probability
It ensures bond prices rise with market rates

questions.explanation: Restricting leverage protects bondholders by reducing risk of future credit deterioration.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond’s Z-spread is measured at 185 bps, while its nominal spread is only 150 bps. What best explains the difference?

options.text: The Z-spread accounts for the entire spot curve rather than only a single yield point
The nominal spread always exceeds the Z-spread
The Z-spread ignores discount factor changes
The nominal spread accounts for embedded options

questions.explanation: Z-spreads use the full Treasury spot curve, often producing wider spreads than nominal spreads.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond’s option-adjusted spread (OAS) is much lower than its Z-spread. What does this indicate?

options.text: The embedded option is significantly valuable to the issuer
The embedded option benefits the investor

questions.explanation: A low OAS relative to Z-spread indicates the option reduces the investor’s expected value due to issuer-friendly features.

questions.questionText: During a recessionary environment, corporate bond spreads typically widen. What is the primary driver of this spread widening?
questions.explanation: Default risk increases during recessions, pushing spreads wider.

questions.questionText: A bond with weak covenant protection trades at a yield 60 bps higher than similar bonds with strong covenants. What is this 60 bps difference called?
questions.explanation: Weaker covenants demand higher yields to compensate for increased risk.

questions.questionText: A high-yield bond is trading at 82% of par. What does this price level typically signal to the market?
questions.explanation: Deep discounts imply significant credit distress concerns.

questions.questionText: A credit analyst evaluates historical recovery rates across bond seniority levels. Which category generally has the lowest recovery rate?
questions.explanation: Subordinated unsecured claims receive payment only after senior classes, leading to lower recoveries.

questions.questionText: Which development most likely causes a tightening of corporate bond credit spreads?
questions.explanation: Better issuer performance lowers perceived default risk, tightening spreads.

questions.questionText: A bond investor values an investment-grade bond with a high coupon. The issuer is experiencing stable leverage and strong liquidity. What risk most likely remains despite the strong fundamentals?

options.text: Interest rate risk due to high coupon cash flows

questions.explanation: High coupons increase interest rate sensitivity of reinvested cash flows.

questions.questionText: During a volatile credit environment, an analyst notices the bid-ask spread on several corporate bonds widening significantly. What risk is most directly associated with this widening?
questions.explanation: Wider bid-ask spreads indicate reduced liquidity, making trading more costly and difficult.

questions.questionText: A corporate issuer’s credit spread tightens by 35 bps after it announces a successful equity capital raise. What is the most likely reason spreads reacted positively?

options.text: New equity improves issuer leverage and reduces credit risk
Equity raises always increase bond coupon payments
Equity issuance lowers the issuer’s liquidity
Bondholders receive a portion of the new equity issuance

questions.explanation: Increasing equity reduces leverage and default risk, tightening spreads.

questions.questionText: A high-yield corporate bond’s price falls sharply even though Treasury yields remain unchanged. Which explanation best describes this movement?

options.text: Credit spreads widened due to perceived credit deterioration

questions.explanation: If Treasury yields are stable but prices fall, credit spreads likely widened.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond contains a change-of-control covenant requiring bond repurchase at 101% of par if the issuer is acquired. Who benefits most from this provision?

options.text: Bondholders because they are protected from leveraged buyouts
Equity holders because they gain call protection
Management because it reduces bond volatility
Underwriters because they receive repurchase fees

questions.explanation: These covenants protect bondholders when leverage spikes after acquisitions.

questions.questionText: A firm with declining sales issues new debt to fund operations. How does this likely impact its outstanding bonds?

options.text: Spreads widen due to increased leverage and default risk
Bond prices rise due to improved short-term liquidity
Existing bonds become senior to the new debt

questions.explanation: Issuing debt during financial stress increases leverage and credit risk.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond trades at a deep discount and exhibits a very high yield-to-maturity. What does this typically imply?

options.text: The market expects elevated probability of default
The bond has unusually high convexity
The issuer recently improved its credit rating

questions.explanation: Deep discounts and high yields generally signal severe credit concerns.

questions.questionText: A subordinated bond has a recovery rate historically near 20% in default scenarios. What implication does this have for the bond’s credit spread relative to senior debt?

options.text: Subordinated bonds carry higher spreads to compensate for lower recoveries
Subordinated bonds have lower spreads because they are risk-free
Spreads must always equal those of secured loans
Recovery rates do not affect credit spreads

questions.explanation: Lower recovery rates mean higher required spreads for investors.

questions.questionText: An analyst compares a callable corporate bond to an identical non-callable bond. Why does the callable bond typically trade at a higher yield?

options.text: Callability exposes investors to reinvestment risk when rates fall
Callable bonds always have higher recovery rates
Callable bonds eliminate interest rate risk

questions.explanation: Call options benefit the issuer, not the investor, requiring yield compensation.

questions.questionText: A company's CDS spread widens rapidly over the course of a week. What does this most likely imply for its outstanding corporate bonds?

options.text: Bond prices fall as credit risk perception increases

questions.explanation: Higher CDS spreads indicate higher default risk, lowering bond prices.

questions.questionText: Two corporate bonds have the same OAS, but Bond A has a significantly higher Z-spread. What explains this?

options.text: Bond A contains a valuable embedded option that reduces OAS

questions.explanation: A higher Z-spread but similar OAS indicates a costly (issuer-benefiting) option embedded in the bond.

questions.questionText: During a credit rally, corporate spreads compress rapidly. Which group benefits most from spread tightening?

options.text: New bond buyers through higher yields
Equity investors because dividends increase automatically

questions.explanation: Spread tightening increases bond prices, benefiting current holders.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond is downgraded from BBB to BB, placing it into high-yield territory. What is the most immediate impact on institutional demand?

options.text: Some investment-grade–only investors may be forced to sell
Demand increases from investment-grade index funds
Income distributions on the bond rise automatically

questions.explanation: Forced selling happens when bonds fall outside investment mandates.

questions.questionText: An issuer’s bonds exhibit a much higher liquidity premium than peers, even though default risk is similar. What factor likely contributes most?

options.text: The issuer has limited secondary market trading activity
The issuer has an unusually strong balance sheet
The issuer offers superior covenant protection

questions.explanation: Low trading frequency raises transaction costs, increasing liquidity premiums.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond has a make-whole call provision. How does this differ from a standard call provision?

options.text: It compensates investors for lost coupon value by discounting future cash flows
It allows issuers to call at any time without penalty
It guarantees higher recovery rates in default

questions.explanation: Make-whole calls reimburse investors based on discounted future payments, making them more investor-friendly.

questions.questionText: A bond trades at a spread of 75 bps, while similar bonds in the sector trade at 110 bps. Which condition most likely explains the tighter spread?

options.text: The issuer has stronger credit fundamentals
The issuer is in financial distress

questions.explanation: Stronger fundamentals justify tighter spreads.

questions.questionText: A company with a highly cyclical business model issues debt. Which bond feature would investors likely demand to compensate for elevated risk?
questions.explanation: Cyclical firms exhibit volatile earnings, requiring higher spreads to compensate for default risk.

questions.questionText: During a sharp rise in interest rates, investment-grade corporate bonds underperform Treasuries of similar maturities. What is the primary cause?

options.text: Credit spreads widen during economic uncertainty
Corporate bonds have no interest rate sensitivity

questions.explanation: Rates often rise during tightening cycles, increasing recession fears and widening credit spreads.

questions.questionText: A bond’s credit spread narrows even though its credit rating remains unchanged. What best explains this?

options.text: Market-implied credit risk improved faster than ratings can be updated
Ratings always lag spreads by exactly one year
Spreads are unaffected by market sentiment

questions.explanation: Markets price credit risk continuously, while rating changes are infrequent.

questions.questionText: A homeowner takes out a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. Early in the mortgage life, most of the monthly payment goes toward interest rather than principal. What explains this pattern?

options.text: Interest is calculated on the full outstanding balance early in the loan
Principal is not repaid until the final years
Mortgage rates automatically decline over time
Interest and principal payments are randomly assigned

questions.explanation: Amortization structures allocate more interest early because the outstanding balance is highest.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool consists of thousands of individual loans. After the first year, the pool experiences a voluntary prepayment rate far above historical averages. Which factor is the most likely driver?
questions.explanation: Lower rates incentivize refinancing, one of the main sources of prepayments.

questions.questionText: An investor holding a pass-through MBS notices that its duration declines significantly after mortgage rates fall. What best explains the shortening of duration?

options.text: Prepayment speeds accelerate as borrowers refinance
Cash flows are converted to bullet payments

questions.explanation: Lower mortgage rates increase refinancing incentives, accelerating prepayments and reducing duration.

questions.questionText: An analyst compares agency and non-agency MBS. Agency MBS trade at tighter spreads despite similar collateral quality. What is the primary reason?

options.text: Agency MBS benefit from explicit or implicit government guarantees
Non-agency MBS always contain callable structures
Agency MBS have higher default rates
Non-agency pools have no prepayment risk

questions.explanation: Agency guarantees reduce credit risk and tighten spreads.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool has high turnover because borrowers frequently move. How does this affect prepayment behavior?

options.text: Turnover contributes to prepayments independently of interest rate incentives
Turnover collapses when mortgage rates rise
Turnover only occurs when housing prices fall

questions.explanation: Turnover is a structural prepayment component unrelated to refinancing dynamics.

questions.questionText: Which statement best describes the mechanics of a mortgage pass-through security?

options.text: Investors receive pro rata shares of principal and interest after servicing fees
Principal is repaid only at maturity
Cash flows are guaranteed by private insurers only

questions.explanation: Pass-throughs allocate all borrower payments (minus fees) to investors.

questions.questionText: In a dollar roll transaction, an investor sells a pass-through MBS and agrees to repurchase a similar one later. What is the economic purpose of this strategy?

options.text: To earn the 'drop' by temporarily lending the security
To increase duration without adding leverage
To convert mortgage cash flows into fixed coupons

questions.explanation: Dollar rolls generate a return based on the difference between sale and repurchase prices.

questions.questionText: A non-agency MBS pool experiences rising delinquencies. How does this typically affect cash flows to senior tranches?

options.text: Senior tranches are protected until losses exceed credit enhancement
Senior tranches immediately absorb all losses
Losses are allocated equally across tranches

questions.explanation: Senior tranches are protected by subordinate tranches through credit enhancement structures.

questions.questionText: An investor modeling prepayments separates them into refinancing, turnover, defaults, and curtailments. What best describes curtailments?

options.text: Full principal repayment following property sale

questions.explanation: Curtailments refer to partial extra payments toward principal.

questions.questionText: Mortgage pass-through securities exhibit negative convexity. What does this imply about their price behavior?

options.text: They appreciate less than comparable bonds when yields fall
Their duration increases when yields fall
They are unaffected by interest rate changes

questions.explanation: Negative convexity arises because falling rates accelerate prepayments, limiting price appreciation.

questions.questionText: An investor evaluates a mortgage pool using discount factors applied to projected monthly cash flows. Which element makes discounting MBS cash flows more complex than discounting Treasury bonds?

options.text: Uncertain timing of cash flows due to prepayments

questions.explanation: Prepayments cause path-dependent cash flows, complicating valuation.

questions.questionText: A mortgage-backed security trades at a yield spread of 85 bps. After adjusting for the borrower's prepayment option, the option-adjusted spread (OAS) is only 42 bps. What does the difference represent?

options.text: The prepayment option reduces investor value, inflating the nominal spread
The OAS incorrectly ignores default risk
The MBS is risk-free after option adjustment
The prepayment option increases convexity benefits to investors

questions.explanation: The difference between spread and OAS reflects the embedded prepayment option cost.

questions.questionText: A mortgage borrower defaults. What effect does this have on a pass-through MBS investor?

options.text: The investor receives remaining principal but loses interest payments
Interest payments increase due to delinquency penalties

questions.explanation: Defaults return principal but halt interest, reducing cash flow yield.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool has high seasoning, with many loans already partially paid down. How does seasoning typically affect prepayment behavior?

options.text: Seasoned loans tend to prepay more slowly unless refinancing incentives are strong
Seasoned loans exhibit no refinancing behavior

questions.explanation: Seasoned pools often have lower turnover unless strong rate incentives drive refinancing.

questions.questionText: Why does an agency MBS typically carry lower credit risk than a non-agency MBS?

options.text: Agency MBS offer government-backed guarantees on principal and interest
Agency loans have no prepayment risk
Agency MBS always have shorter maturities

questions.explanation: GSE guarantees significantly reduce credit risk exposure.

questions.questionText: An investor examines the refinancing component of a mortgage model. Which factor most directly increases refinancing rates?

options.text: Mortgage rates falling below borrowers’ existing rates
An increase in borrower credit scores

questions.explanation: Borrowers refinance when new rates fall sufficiently below current mortgage rates.

questions.questionText: MBS investors face uncertainty due to prepayments. Which risk does this uncertainty most directly manifest as?

options.text: Duration risk only, without reinvestment effects

questions.explanation: Investors may be forced to reinvest principal at lower yields when prepayments accelerate.

questions.questionText: Mortgage-backed securities often rely on Monte Carlo simulation for valuation. What feature makes simulation necessary?

options.text: Prepayment behavior depends on future interest rate paths
Cash flows are independent of rate volatility

questions.explanation: Path-dependent prepayment dynamics require modeling interest rate paths to determine cash flows.

questions.questionText: A borrower pays off a mortgage earlier than scheduled due to a job relocation. The mortgage rate environment has not changed significantly. What is the most likely prepayment category for this payoff?
questions.explanation: Turnover prepayments occur when borrowers move, independent of interest rate incentives.

questions.questionText: In analyzing an amortization table, an investor notes that the principal portion of the monthly payment grows each month. What explains this trend?

options.text: Interest is paid on a declining balance, allowing more of the payment to go to principal
The mortgage rate increases over time
Borrowers make interest-only payments in early years
Principal payments are pre-determined and fixed for each month

questions.explanation: As the balance declines, interest charges fall, increasing the principal share of payments.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool has a constant prepayment rate (CPR) of 8%. The corresponding single monthly mortality (SMM) rate is required for valuation. Approximately what is the SMM?
An analyst evaluating refinancing prepayments finds that prepayment speeds remain slow even though mortgage rates have fallen significantly. What is the most likely explanation?

options.text: Borrowers face high refinancing costs or credit constraints
Seasoned pools are not affected by interest rate changes
Turnover is the only driver of prepayments

questions.explanation: Costs, credit limits, or documentation barriers reduce refinancing responsiveness.

questions.questionText: A pass-through MBS distributes monthly cash flows to investors. During periods of rapidly falling interest rates, how is cash flow timing affected?

options.text: Cash flows accelerate due to increased refinancing
Cash flows slow down due to declining defaults
Cash flows become fixed and predictable
Cash flows are unaffected by prepayment behavior

questions.explanation: Lower rates stimulate refinancing, accelerating principal payments.

questions.questionText: Compared with a Treasury bond, a pass-through MBS demonstrates significantly lower convexity. What is the most likely cause?

options.text: Embedded prepayment option held by borrowers

questions.explanation: Negative convexity arises because prepayments limit upside when rates fall.

questions.questionText: An investor performs OAS analysis on an MBS. After running multiple interest rate paths, the OAS appears extremely sensitive to volatility assumptions. Why?

options.text: Prepayment behavior depends heavily on the path of interest rate volatility
Cash flows are fixed regardless of interest rates
Agency guarantees eliminate interest rate sensitivity

questions.explanation: Volatility alters refinancing incentives, changing prepayment paths and OAS results.

questions.questionText: A large portion of loans in a mortgage pool has loan-to-value (LTV) ratios above 95%. What risk characteristic does this imply?

options.text: Higher default probability due to limited borrower equity

questions.explanation: High LTV borrowers have weaker financial positions, increasing default risk.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool exhibits a rapid rise in curtailments during a stable interest rate environment. What is the most plausible driver?

options.text: Borrowers are making extra principal payments without refinancing
Turnover is increasing due to refinancing
All prepayments are due to refinancing effects

questions.explanation: Curtailments represent partial principal payments unrelated to rate-driven refinancing.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool is issued by Fannie Mae. Which risk does the agency guarantee eliminate?
questions.explanation: Agency guarantees protect principal and interest from credit losses, but not prepayment or rate risk.

questions.questionText: Why do seasoned mortgage pools typically exhibit lower refinancing rates than newly originated pools?

options.text: Remaining balances are smaller, reducing refinancing benefit
Seasoned loans have higher default rates
Seasoned loans are protected from prepayment
Borrowers cannot refinance after five years

questions.explanation: Lower balances reduce potential savings from refinancing, lowering refinancing sensitivity.

questions.questionText: A mortgage-backed security is priced using Monte Carlo simulation. What is the key output produced by simulating multiple interest rate paths?

options.text: Exact repayment dates for all borrowers

questions.explanation: Monte Carlo models generate probability-weighted cash flows based on rate-dependent prepayments.

questions.questionText: In a non-agency MBS, credit enhancement absorbs losses before they reach senior tranches. Which structure provides this protection?
questions.explanation: Subordination allocates losses to lower tranches, protecting senior notes.

questions.questionText: A mortgage pool contains adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs). How does this feature affect prepayment behavior?

options.text: ARMs reduce refinancing sensitivity to interest rate changes
ARMs guarantee faster prepayments than fixed-rate mortgages
ARMs remove all borrower rate incentives

questions.explanation: ARMs adjust with market rates, reducing refinancing motivation when rates move.

questions.questionText: An MBS trades at a significant discount to par due to expectations of slow prepayments. What feature most strongly contributes to its discounted price?
questions.explanation: Slow prepayments extend cash flows, increasing duration and discounting value.

questions.questionText: Which mortgage feature most directly reduces the likelihood of default?
questions.explanation: Low LTV borrowers have equity cushions, lowering default risk.

questions.questionText: Why does prepayment uncertainty make MBS valuation more difficult than valuing a bullet corporate bond?

options.text: MBS cash flows are path-dependent and vary with borrower behavior
Corporate bonds have no credit risk
MBS cash flows occur only at maturity
Corporate bonds are paid monthly like MBS

questions.explanation: Prepayments cause uncertainty in timing and amount of cash flows, unlike fixed cash-flow bonds.

questions.questionText: In a dollar roll, the investor typically gives up principal and interest payments during the roll period. What compensates for this loss?

options.text: The 'drop' between the sale and forward repurchase price

questions.explanation: The drop compensates for foregone cash flows during the dollar roll period.

questions.questionText: An MBS investor evaluates the pool’s seasoning. Why might highly seasoned pools be attractive during rising rate environments?

options.text: Seasoned pools often have slower prepayment speeds and reduced refinancing options
Seasoned pools automatically refinance when rates rise

questions.explanation: Seasoned pools have already experienced early prepayments, reducing sensitivity to rising rates.

questions.questionText: An asset manager uses Treasury bond futures to hedge a long-duration bond portfolio. After a sharp decline in yields, the hedge underperforms significantly. What is the most likely explanation?

options.text: Basis risk caused the futures and cash bond prices to move differently
Futures perfectly tracked the portfolio duration
Delivery options eliminate all hedging error
Interest rate futures benefit from negative convexity

questions.explanation: Cash bonds and futures rarely move in perfect lockstep, generating basis risk.

questions.questionText: A Treasury futures contract is nearing delivery. The cheapest-to-deliver (CTD) bond shifts from a 10-year note to an 8-year note. What is the most likely driver of this change?

options.text: Relative yield changes altered the bond with lowest delivery cost
The futures exchange replaced eligible bonds
Only longer-duration bonds can be CTD
Shorter-duration bonds cannot deliver into futures

questions.explanation: Changes in relative yields affect which bond minimizes delivery cost under the conversion factor system.

questions.questionText: A 3-month Eurodollar futures contract trades at 95.60. What is the implied annualized interest rate?
questions.explanation: Eurodollar futures rate = 100 − price = 4.40%.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager hedges a bond position using Treasury futures. The bond has a duration of 7.8, and the futures have a duration of 6.1. Why must the hedge ratio adjust for these sensitivity differences?

options.text: Duration mismatch causes imperfect hedging unless scaled appropriately
Futures always have higher duration than bonds
Bond duration is constant regardless of yields
Futures contracts eliminate interest rate exposure fully

questions.explanation: Effective hedging requires matching interest rate sensitivity across instruments.

questions.questionText: An investor in Treasury futures observes that the futures price trades above the theoretical no-arbitrage price. What arbitrage strategy is appropriate?

options.text: Short the futures and buy the underlying bond
Buy the futures and short the bond
Short both the bond and futures
Buy both the bond and futures

questions.explanation: If futures are overpriced, arbitrageurs sell futures and buy the bond to lock in profit.

questions.questionText: In a Treasury bond futures contract, the conversion factor system is used. What is its purpose?

options.text: To adjust for differences in coupon rates and maturities of deliverable bonds
To equalize credit risk across deliverable bonds
To guarantee a single CTD bond
To stabilize interest rates in the futures market

questions.explanation: Conversion factors normalize price differences among eligible bonds.

questions.questionText: A bank wants to protect itself against rising short-term interest rates. Which futures position is appropriate?
questions.explanation: Eurodollar futures prices fall when rates rise, so selling the futures provides a hedge.

questions.questionText: An investor is long Treasury futures. Yields fall sharply. What happens to the value of the futures position?

options.text: The position is unaffected by interest rates
The position only gains if the CTD changes

questions.explanation: Long futures positions benefit from declining yields, which raise underlying bond prices.

questions.questionText: An investor evaluates the implied repo rate of a Treasury futures arbitrage. What does the implied repo rate represent?

options.text: The return from buying the bond and selling the futures
The rate embedded in Eurodollar futures
The cost of borrowing Fed Funds
The return paid by the exchange for posting margin

questions.explanation: It represents the arbitrage profit of the cash-and-carry strategy.

questions.questionText: A trader hedges a long-term corporate bond with Treasury futures. Despite a duration match, the hedge performs poorly when credit spreads widen. What caused the underperformance?

options.text: The hedge did not cover credit spread risk
Treasury futures contain embedded credit risk
Futures are more sensitive to yield curve shifts than corporate bonds

questions.explanation: Credit spread changes are not hedged using Treasury futures.

questions.questionText: A firm uses Treasury bond futures to decrease the duration of its bond portfolio. Which action correctly reduces portfolio duration?

options.text: Purchase STRIPS and hold to maturity

questions.explanation: Selling futures reduces interest rate sensitivity of the overall portfolio.

questions.questionText: An investor calculates the theoretical price of a Treasury futures contract using the cost-of-carry model. Which factor is NOT part of the calculation?
questions.explanation: The cost-of-carry model depends on financing, coupons, and time, but not inflation expectations.

questions.questionText: If the CTD bond has a conversion factor of 0.90 and a quoted futures price of 122-16, what is the invoice price (ignoring accrued interest)?
questions.explanation: Invoice price = futures price × conversion factor. 122.5 × 0.90 ≈ 110.25.

questions.questionText: Interest rate futures are marked to market daily. What is the primary implication of this feature?

options.text: Gains and losses are realized and transferred each day
Only the final settlement matters for P&L

questions.explanation: Daily settlement transfers gains and losses through margining.

questions.questionText: When interest rate volatility increases sharply, what is the most likely effect on Treasury futures prices?

options.text: Futures become more sensitive to CTD option value
Futures prices detach from underlying bonds permanently

questions.explanation: Volatility increases the value of delivery options, affecting futures pricing.

questions.questionText: A corporate treasurer expects interest rates to decline and wants to lock in lower borrowing costs for future debt issuance. Which futures strategy is appropriate?

options.text: Buy Treasury futures to benefit from falling yields

questions.explanation: Buying futures profits from declining yields, locking in lower cost of future borrowing.

questions.questionText: If the basis between a bond and its corresponding futures contract unexpectedly widens, what risk has increased?
questions.explanation: Basis risk reflects divergence between cash and futures prices.

questions.questionText: A short hedger sells interest rate futures. Unexpectedly, interest rates fall. What happens to the hedging position?

options.text: The short futures position incurs a loss
The position automatically converts to a long hedge

questions.explanation: Futures prices rise when rates fall, creating losses for short positions.

questions.questionText: A bank hedges its short-term funding costs with Eurodollar futures. The bank expects borrowing costs to rise over the next year. However, geopolitical tension causes a flight to quality, sharply reducing interest rates. How is the hedge affected?

options.text: The hedge loses value because rates fell unexpectedly
The hedge gains because Eurodollar prices fall when rates fall
The hedge is unaffected because short-term rates are stable

questions.explanation: Selling Eurodollar futures profits when rates rise; if rates fall, the short future loses money.

questions.questionText: In a Treasury bond futures contract, the short has the option to choose the delivery date within the delivery month. Why does this option have value?

options.text: It allows the short to minimize financing cost by timing delivery strategically
It guarantees the futures price remains constant
It forces the buyer to accept higher-yielding bonds

questions.explanation: The timing option helps the short optimize delivery based on changing interest rates and financing conditions.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager hedges a municipal bond portfolio with Treasury futures. After a credit scare in the municipal market, muni yields rise while Treasury yields fall. What explains the hedge failure?

options.text: The hedge did not account for spread widening between munis and Treasuries
Treasury futures embed municipal credit risk
Futures hedges always break down when volatility rises
Duration matching fully hedges credit spreads

questions.explanation: Treasury futures hedge interest rate risk, not credit spread movements in muni bonds.

questions.questionText: A trader calculates the basis on a Treasury futures contract: Basis = Cash Price − (Futures Price × Conversion Factor). What does a positive and widening basis indicate?

options.text: Cash bond outperforms futures due to demand or scarcity
Futures are outperforming the cash market

questions.explanation: A widening positive basis indicates cash bonds appreciating relative to futures, often due to scarcity.

questions.questionText: Eurodollar futures settle based on 3-month LIBOR. Which feature makes them a good proxy for hedging short-term interest rate exposure?

options.text: Eurodollar futures reflect forward expectations of short-term interest rates
Eurodollar futures are uncorrelated with central bank policy
Eurodollar futures contain no basis risk

questions.explanation: Their settlement value directly reflects expected future 3-month rates.

questions.questionText: A trader executes a cash-and-carry arbitrage after observing an overpriced futures contract. What position must the trader hold during the delivery period?

options.text: Long the bond and short the futures
Short both the bond and futures
Long the futures and short the bond

questions.explanation: Overpriced futures are exploited by buying the bond and selling futures, locking in arbitrage profit.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager uses interest rate futures to hedge a bond position, but the hedge ratio is computed incorrectly because the futures duration was estimated under a flat yield curve. Why may this cause hedge inefficiency?

options.text: Futures sensitivity varies by yield curve shape, not just level
Bond duration does not depend on the yield curve
Yield curves flatten and steepen at the same rate

questions.explanation: Duration of futures changes with curve shape, causing errors if curve shifts are not modeled properly.

questions.questionText: The CTD bond for a Treasury futures contract changes unexpectedly after a steepening of the yield curve. Why does a yield curve steepening often change CTD selection?

options.text: Longer-duration bonds become cheaper on a relative basis
The exchange restricts CTD options under steep curves
Conversion factors change daily with yields

questions.explanation: Steepening increases yields at long maturities, often making long-duration bonds relatively cheaper to deliver.

questions.questionText: A bank holds a large floating-rate loan portfolio and is concerned about declining interest income. What futures position can hedge this risk?
questions.explanation: Buying Eurodollar futures profits when interest rates fall, offsetting lower floating-rate income.

questions.questionText: A Treasury futures contract has a theoretical price of 118, but the market price is 117.1. What strategy profits from this discrepancy?

options.text: Buy futures and short the bond
Short futures and buy the bond
Buy both futures and the bond
Short both futures and the bond

questions.explanation: Underpriced futures call for buying futures and shorting the bond (reverse cash-and-carry).

questions.questionText: A firm calculates hedge effectiveness using regression and finds an R² of 0.92 between changes in futures prices and portfolio value changes. What does this imply?

options.text: The futures contract explains most of the variation in portfolio interest-rate exposure
Futures prices are uncorrelated with the portfolio

questions.explanation: A high R² indicates strong correlation and potential hedging effectiveness.

questions.questionText: A trader notes that the implied repo rate from a cash-and-carry arbitrage is below the prevailing repo rate. What does this indicate?

options.text: The arbitrage is unprofitable and should not be executed
The futures are overpriced and present arbitrage opportunity
The futures are underpriced and profitable for arbitrage

questions.explanation: If implied repo < actual repo, arbitrage does not cover financing cost and is unprofitable.

questions.questionText: During delivery, the short in a Treasury futures contract chooses to deliver a bond with the lowest cost basis. What principle explains this behavior?
questions.explanation: Shorts always deliver the bond with minimum delivery cost.

questions.questionText: Stochastic rate models tend to value interest rate futures differently from deterministic models. Why?

options.text: Interest rate volatility and path-dependency influence futures valuation
Futures pay coupons that depend on volatility

questions.explanation: Stochastic rates introduce convexity effects and expectation biases not captured in deterministic models.

questions.questionText: A pension fund uses interest rate futures to hedge liabilities with a duration of 15. Treasury futures only have a duration of 7. What must be done to properly hedge?

options.text: Increase the number of futures contracts to match duration exposure
Use fewer contracts to reduce over-hedging
Eliminate futures hedging and use cash bonds only

questions.explanation: More futures are needed because they provide less sensitivity than the portfolio being hedged.

questions.questionText: If interest rate futures prices begin reacting strongly to small movements in yields, what risk is increasing?
questions.explanation: Convexity and non-linear sensitivity increase when rates move significantly or rapidly.

questions.questionText: Why does the exchange require both initial and variation margin for interest rate futures?

options.text: To protect against counterparty default and daily price changes
To guarantee the futures price remains constant

questions.explanation: Initial margin protects against default; variation margin manages daily mark-to-market exposure.

questions.questionText: A trader sells Treasury futures expecting interest rates to rise. However, the futures price rises instead because the CTD bond switches to a lower-duration issue. What happened?

options.text: CTD switching altered futures sensitivity to interest rates
Futures became immune to rate changes
Treasury yields did not influence futures pricing

questions.explanation: CTD changes modify the futures’ implicit duration, affecting hedging performance.

questions.questionText: A bank enters an inflation swap paying fixed inflation and receiving realized inflation. What happens if inflation comes in far below expectations?

options.text: The swap loses value because realized inflation is low
The swap gains value because fixed payments fall
The swap is unaffected because inflation swaps hedge interest rates
The swap resets to zero at low inflation

questions.explanation: Receiving realized inflation becomes less valuable when inflation is low.

questions.questionText: Swap netting agreements reduce exposure by combining multiple swap positions into a single payable or receivable. Why is this crucial during stressed markets?

options.text: It prevents large unilateral exposures from accumulating
It increases liquidity risk for both parties
It eliminates the need for collateral

questions.explanation: Netting limits exposure to the single net amount owed after offsetting positions.

questions.questionText: A company uses a commodity swap to hedge long-term input costs but faces seasonal fluctuations in consumption. Why could a mismatch occur?

options.text: The swap may settle monthly while consumption varies irregularly
Commodity swaps perfectly match consumption schedules
Commodity swaps eliminate all timing mismatch
Commodity swaps hedge credit spreads only

questions.explanation: Seasonality creates volume and timing mismatch relative to fixed swap schedules.

questions.questionText: A cross-currency swap involves exchanging fixed USD for floating EUR. If USD interest rates rise while EUR rates remain unchanged, who benefits?

options.text: Neither party benefits because currency effects cancel interest rate effects

questions.explanation: Rising fixed USD payments increase the value of receiving the fixed leg.

questions.questionText: An amortizing interest rate swap matches declining principal payments on a loan. Why is this structure used?

options.text: To match hedge notional to the declining notional of the loan

questions.explanation: Amortizing swaps allow hedgers to match decreasing outstanding loan balances.

questions.questionText: A swap’s sensitivity to interest rates is measured using DV01. Why is DV01 higher for longer-maturity swaps?

options.text: Longer swaps have more distant fixed payments with higher PV sensitivity
Floating legs have no interest sensitivity
DV01 does not depend on maturity

questions.explanation: Long-dated fixed payments react more strongly to yield changes, increasing DV01.

questions.questionText: A corporation enters into a pay-fixed, receive-floating interest rate swap to hedge its floating-rate debt. Six months later, short-term interest rates fall significantly. How is the value of the swap affected?

options.text: The swap loses value because floating payments decline
The swap gains value because fixed payments fall
The swap is unaffected by rate changes
The swap automatically resets to market value

questions.explanation: Receiving floating becomes less valuable when floating rates fall, decreasing the swap's value.

questions.questionText: Two firms face different borrowing costs: Firm A can borrow at 6% fixed or LIBOR + 40 bps floating. Firm B can borrow at 7% fixed or LIBOR + 70 bps floating. Which firm has a comparative advantage in fixed-rate borrowing?

options.text: Comparative advantage cannot be assessed from borrowing rates

questions.explanation: Firm A has a 1% advantage in fixed vs. a 30 bps advantage in floating, thus has the comparative advantage in fixed-rate borrowing.

questions.questionText: An interest rate swap is valued by discounting future fixed and floating payments. Why is the floating leg valued at par immediately after a reset?

options.text: Because the floating payment resets to the prevailing market rate
Because the swap exchange guarantees notional parity
Because floating rates are always higher than fixed rates
Because floating-rate payers assume no interest rate risk

questions.explanation: At reset dates, the floating payment equals the market rate, making its present value equal to notional.

questions.questionText: A bank enters into a receive-fixed currency swap to convert USD cash flows into EUR. When the EUR depreciates sharply relative to USD, what happens to the swap’s value for the bank?

options.text: The swap loses value because the received EUR cash flows are worth less
The swap gains value because EUR cash flows increase
The swap is unaffected by currency movements
The swap value becomes positive because USD depreciates

questions.explanation: Receiving EUR becomes less valuable when the euro weakens.

questions.questionText: A firm enters a commodity swap where it pays fixed and receives floating based on oil prices. If oil prices rise sharply, which party benefits?

options.text: The firm receiving floating oil prices
The fixed payer always loses in swaps
The fixed payer benefits regardless of market movement
Neither party benefits because swaps net to zero

questions.explanation: Receiving floating tied to rising commodity prices increases the swap’s value.

questions.questionText: Why is counterparty credit risk typically lower in interest rate swaps than in loan agreements?

options.text: Swap notional is exchanged at reset
Swap payments are collateralized by law

questions.explanation: Only net amounts (fixed minus floating) are exchanged, reducing credit exposure.

questions.questionText: A pension fund holds long-duration liabilities and wants to reduce duration risk. Which swap position accomplishes this?

options.text: Enter a currency swap converting USD to EUR

questions.explanation: Pay-fixed receive-floating reduces interest rate sensitivity, lowering duration exposure.

questions.questionText: In a plain vanilla interest rate swap, the fixed rate is set such that the swap’s initial value is zero. What condition ensures this?

options.text: Present value of fixed payments equals present value of floating payments
Fixed payments must exceed floating payments
Floating payments must be discounted at the fixed rate
The notional must be exchanged at inception

questions.explanation: Swaps are priced so the net present value of both legs is equal at inception.

questions.questionText: An equity swap pays the total return of a stock index in exchange for a fixed rate. If the index falls 12% over the period, what happens to the equity return payer?

options.text: The payer must make a negative total return payment
The payer receives additional fixed payments
The swap nets to zero and no payments occur
The payer receives the 12% as a positive cash flow

questions.explanation: Equity return payer must make payments when total return is negative.

questions.questionText: If the discount curve shifts upward uniformly, what happens to the value of a pay-fixed, receive-floating swap?

options.text: It gains value because fixed-rate liabilities become less costly relative to floating
It loses value because floating-rate receipts decline
It is unaffected because swaps are interest rate neutral
It resets to zero at each payment

questions.explanation: Higher discount rates reduce the PV of fixed payments more than floating payments, benefiting the fixed payer.

questions.questionText: A corporation enters a currency swap exchanging USD fixed payments for JPY floating payments. What is the firm’s primary exposure?

options.text: Exchange rate risk between USD and JPY

questions.explanation: Currency swaps expose firms to changes in relative exchange rates.

questions.questionText: Why do swap dealers typically hedge their interest rate swaps using government bond futures or interest rate futures?

options.text: To offset interest rate risk created by receiving or paying fixed legs
To eliminate all counterparty credit exposure

questions.explanation: Dealers hedge mismatches between fixed and floating exposures with futures.

questions.questionText: At the start of a swap, the fixed rate is higher than the expected floating rate over the life of the contract. Why is this normal?

options.text: The fixed rate embeds a risk premium for locking in long-term rates
The fixed rate must equal zero for a fair swap
Floating rates always exceed fixed rates
Fixed rates cannot be valued using discount factors

questions.explanation: Long-term fixed rates include term premium relative to expected floating rates.

questions.questionText: A firm hedges equity market exposure by paying the total return of an index and receiving a fixed rate. What risk remains after this swap?

options.text: Dividend uncertainty risk is fully eliminated

questions.explanation: The swap transfers market exposure, but counterparty risk persists.

questions.questionText: A commodity swap includes monthly settlement of net payments. Why does this reduce credit exposure compared to annual settlement?

options.text: Frequent settlement prevents the build-up of large net exposures
Short settlement periods eliminate all credit risk
Commodity swaps must settle monthly by regulation

questions.explanation: More frequent settlement reduces cumulative unpaid exposure, lowering credit risk.

questions.questionText: Which statement best describes netting in swap agreements?

options.text: Only the net payment between the two swap legs is exchanged
The notional amount is exchanged at each payment date
Netting eliminates the need for collateral
Netting requires physical delivery of assets

questions.explanation: Netting lowers credit exposure by exchanging only net obligations.

questions.questionText: An interest rate swap’s mark-to-market value becomes highly positive for the fixed-rate payer. What risk does the fixed payer now face?

options.text: Counterparty default on the positive exposure
Floating rate payments increase in size

questions.explanation: When the swap is positive, the payer risks losing value if the counterparty defaults.

questions.questionText: A corporation enters into a fixed-for-floating interest rate swap to hedge bond issuance six months in the future. What risk does this hedge attempt to mitigate?

options.text: Interest rate risk prior to issuance
Credit spread risk on existing debt

questions.explanation: The swap locks in borrowing costs before actual debt issuance.

questions.questionText: Company A enters a pay-fixed, receive-floating swap because it expects interest rates to rise. Instead, rates fall steadily over the next year. Treasury yields shift downward, and the floating reference resets lower each quarter. What happens to the market value of the swap for Company A?

options.text: It becomes negative because floating payments decline
It remains at zero because swaps always reset
It becomes positive because fixed payments decrease
It becomes positive because lower rates benefit fixed payers

questions.explanation: Pay-fixed, receive-floating becomes less favorable when floating rates drop.

questions.questionText: A bank enters a cross-currency swap converting USD fixed payments into GBP floating payments. Three months later, GBP interest rates spike following unexpected inflation data. What impact does this have on the swap for the bank receiving floating GBP?

options.text: The swap gains value because floating payments rise
The swap loses value because fixed USD payments fall
The swap is unaffected because currency swaps hedge inflation
The swap resets to zero due to higher volatility

questions.explanation: Higher floating payments increase the value to the floating receiver.

questions.questionText: A swap dealer offsets most of its swap exposure through back-to-back trades. However, one counterparty becomes distressed and stops posting collateral. The dealer’s market value on that trade is significantly positive. What risk is the dealer now exposed to?

options.text: Counterparty credit risk due to positive exposure
Interest rate risk from swap mismatching

questions.explanation: Positive MTM means the dealer stands to lose if the counterparty defaults.

questions.questionText: Firm A and Firm B want to borrow in different markets. Firm A has a comparative advantage in fixed-rate borrowing, while Firm B has a comparative advantage in floating-rate borrowing. What structured transaction allows both firms to benefit?
questions.explanation: Interest rate swaps let each firm borrow where it is strongest and exchange exposures.

questions.questionText: An investor enters into an equity swap paying LIBOR and receiving total return on a stock index. Over the next quarter, the index rises but LIBOR also increases sharply. How does this affect the investor’s net position?

options.text: Net benefit depends on whether index return exceeds the floating payment
The investor always profits because equity rises
The investor always loses when LIBOR rises
The swap resets to zero regardless of index performance

questions.explanation: The net outcome is TR(index) – LIBOR, so both movements matter.

questions.questionText: In a currency swap, notional amounts are exchanged at both inception and maturity. Why does this create significant credit exposure compared with interest rate swaps?

options.text: Because full principal amounts are exchanged, not just net payments
Because currency swaps are uncollateralized by definition
Because interest rate swaps always terminate early
Because FX rates cannot be hedged

questions.explanation: Principal exchanges greatly increase credit exposure when exchange rates move.

questions.questionText: A trader observes that the fixed rate on a new interest rate swap is above the par swap rate implied by the discount curve. What does this indicate about the swap’s value at inception?

options.text: The fixed payer receives value and the fixed receiver pays value
The swap must be worth zero at inception
The swap must be terminated immediately

questions.explanation: Fixed rate above par gives value to the party paying fixed (since fixed payments are relatively smaller).

questions.questionText: During periods of rising credit stress, swap spreads—defined as the swap fixed rate minus the yield of a comparable Treasury—often widen. Why does this occur?

options.text: Counterparty credit risk increases, requiring higher fixed swap rates
Treasury yields rise faster than swap rates
Swap notional must be exchanged during stress periods
Swap spreads widen due to equity volatility

questions.explanation: Swap spreads incorporate counterparty credit risk, unlike Treasuries.

questions.questionText: A company enters a commodity swap paying floating prices on natural gas and receiving fixed. If natural gas prices collapse, what is the immediate effect on the swap’s MTM value for the company?

options.text: The swap loses value because floating payments decrease
The swap gains value because fixed payments increase
The swap is unaffected because commodity prices are volatile
The swap resets to zero after price collapse

questions.explanation: Floating payer loses when floating commodity prices fall.

questions.questionText: A swaption gives its holder the right to enter into a swap at a future date. What type of exposure does a payer swaption hedge?

options.text: Risk of rising fixed interest rates
Risk of falling fixed interest rates

questions.explanation: A payer swaption is a right to pay fixed, which benefits when rates rise.

questions.questionText: A floating-rate note referencing 3-month LIBOR is hedged using a receive-floating interest rate swap. If LIBOR becomes highly volatile, what residual risk remains?

options.text: Basis risk due to differences in reset dates or conventions

questions.explanation: Mismatch in timing or reference curves generates basis risk even for matching indices.

questions.questionText: Why do swap dealers use OIS discounting when valuing collateralized swaps?

options.text: Because collateral earns an overnight rate
Because OIS rates are always higher than LIBOR
Because swaps must be valued using Treasury yields
Because fixed legs must be discounted using swap rates

questions.explanation: Post-crisis pricing uses OIS curves for collateralized derivatives.

questions.questionText: A firm enters a 3-year annual-pay interest rate swap where it pays fixed and receives floating. At inception the swap is at par with a fixed rate of 3.2%. After one year, the remaining 2-year swap fixed rate falls to 2.6%. What is the value of the existing swap to the fixed-rate payer?

options.text: Negative, because fixed is now above market
Positive, because fixed is now above market
Zero, because floating resets each year

questions.explanation: Paying fixed above current swap rate creates negative MTM for the fixed payer; swap value is opposite sign of fixed-rate deviation.

questions.questionText: A swap dealer quotes a 2-year semiannual-pay swap. Zero rates imply discount factors of 0.98 and 0.955 for the two payment periods. What is the par fixed rate if floating resets to par each period?
questions.explanation: Par swap rate = (1 − final DF)/sum(DFs × accrual). Numerator = 1 − 0.955 = 0.045. Denominator ≈ 0.98×0.5 + 0.955×0.5 = 0.9675. ≈ 0.045/0.9675 = 4.9%.
