questions.questionText: A large regional bank relies heavily on VaR to manage its trading book. During a sudden spike in volatility, losses exceed VaR several days in a row. Senior management asks why VaR failed to anticipate such moves. What key limitation of VaR does this scenario highlight?

options.text: VaR is forward-looking and overreacts to future scenarios
VaR is backward-looking and assumes the future resembles historical patterns
VaR always overestimates losses in volatile markets
VaR includes knock-on effects that distort results

questions.explanation: VaR is typically backward-looking and assumes historical distributions continue, which can fail during regime shifts or extreme events.

questions.questionText: A global investment firm wants to test how its portfolio would behave if equity markets repeated the severe declines of 2008. Analysts replicate the exact 12-month changes in market factors from that year. What type of scenario construction is being used?
questions.explanation: Historical scenarios directly replicate movements observed during a past stressed period.

questions.questionText: A bank models a severe recession where GDP drops 3% and unemployment rises 4%. Analysts then extrapolate how corporate default rates will behave based on rating-agency historical data. Which variables are being derived as peripheral variables?

options.text: Default rates inferred from macroeconomic conditions

questions.explanation: Peripheral variables are derived from the specified core macroeconomic variables such as GDP and unemployment.

questions.questionText: A bank performs reverse stress testing and finds that if equity markets fell 40% and corporate spreads widened 500 bps, the bank would breach minimum capital levels. What is the purpose of this reverse stress-test conclusion?

options.text: To identify scenarios that could lead to institutional failure
To meet regulatory minimum modelling standards

questions.explanation: Reverse stress testing identifies combinations of events that would threaten an institution’s viability.

questions.questionText: Following a liquidity shock in credit markets, a bank sells assets rapidly, causing spreads to widen further and amplifying losses. Which concept does this unintended amplification illustrate?
questions.explanation: Knock-on effects occur when firms’ reactions to stress exacerbate the underlying scenario.

questions.questionText: A bank magnifies a mildly adverse six-month historical scenario by tripling all risk-factor movements. The results indicate extreme losses not observed historically. Which modelling challenge does this approach risk?

options.text: Assuming linearity when relationships become nonlinear in stress

questions.explanation: Simply scaling movements ignores nonlinear behavior and rising correlations under stressed conditions.

questions.questionText: A European bank relies on a set of stress scenarios created three years ago. Regulators later find that the bank did not adjust the scenarios despite major macroeconomic shifts. What governance failure occurred?

options.text: Failure to conduct annual model back-testing
Failure to update stress scenarios as risks evolved
Failure to maintain adequate vendor documentation

questions.explanation: Stress scenarios must be updated as new risks emerge; static scenarios undermine governance frameworks.

questions.questionText: Management requests an enterprise-wide stress test using a scenario where global GDP drops 2%, equity markets fall 30%, and credit spreads double. Multiple business units must use the same scenario. Why is this requirement important?

options.text: It avoids double counting of risk in market models
It ensures aggregation of results for an enterprise-wide view
It reduces the number of stress test metrics required by regulators

questions.explanation: Consistent scenarios across business lines allow aggregation and identification of firm-wide vulnerabilities.

questions.questionText: A bank’s stressed VaR sharply increases after incorporating data from a 12-month crisis period. The CRO notes that this change reflects a conditional distribution. What does this mean for stressed VaR?

options.text: It models only the average loss beyond VaR
It assumes the next year will resemble a specific past stressed period
It includes probabilities for all possible outcomes
It automatically incorporates knock-on effects from other banks

questions.explanation: Stressed VaR is a conditional measure based on a repeat of a selected stressed historical window.

questions.questionText: During model validation, reviewers find that the bank’s stress-testing model assumes historical correlations remain constant under crisis conditions. Why is this problematic?

options.text: Correlations typically decrease during crisis conditions
Correlations typically increase in stressed markets
Correlation assumptions are irrelevant for stress testing
Historical correlations are never used in risk modelling

questions.explanation: During stress, correlations often rise (“correlation breakdown”), making constant-correlation assumptions unreliable.

questions.questionText: A bank considers a hypothetical stress scenario involving a sovereign debt default, even though this has never occurred in that region. Why is this scenario still valid?

options.text: Stress tests must only use unprecedented scenarios
Stress testing includes plausible but not historically observed risks
Historical scenarios must be replaced each year

questions.explanation: Stress testing is forward-looking and includes scenarios that have not previously occurred but remain plausible.

questions.questionText: A bank undergoing CCAR is informed that its capital level under the severely adverse scenario falls below regulatory minimums. What is the likely consequence?

options.text: The bank must immediately halt all trading activity
The bank will be required to restrict dividends and raise capital
The bank must switch from VaR to ES for internal modelling
The bank is automatically placed into resolution

questions.explanation: Failing CCAR typically triggers restrictions on capital distributions and may require raising additional capital.

questions.questionText: During a stress-test governance review, auditors discover that the same analyst designs scenarios, builds the models, and validates them. What governance principle is being violated?

options.text: Segregation between scenario design, modelling, and independent review

questions.explanation: Independent review must be separated from modelling and scenario creation to avoid bias.

questions.questionText: A bank creates a scenario with a 25% equity decline, 200 bps rate increase, and 100% rise in volatility. Why is this considered a key-variable stress scenario?

options.text: It is derived from a historical crisis period
It stresses specific risk factors rather than replaying a full historical period

questions.explanation: Key-variable scenarios specify large moves in selected risk factors rather than replicating past periods.

questions.questionText: An insurer evaluates a 30-year scenario involving a decline in mortality rates, affecting annuity liabilities. Why is such a long horizon appropriate?

options.text: Longevity risk materializes over decades, not months
Stress testing must always use 30-year horizons

questions.explanation: Certain risks such as longevity develop over very long timescales, requiring extended stress horizons.

questions.questionText: A bank’s liquidity stress test shows that under an adverse scenario, funding costs rise sharply due to market distrust of counterparties. What type of risk interaction is being illustrated?
questions.explanation: Counterparty credit concerns can rapidly escalate into liquidity shocks, showing risk interactions.

questions.questionText: A firm conducts a stress test but senior management dismisses its results as unrealistic and does not incorporate them into capital planning. What key governance failure does this represent?

options.text: Failure of senior management to engage and act on stress-test results

questions.explanation: Basel principles require senior management involvement, challenge, and integration of results into decisions.

questions.questionText: A bank attempts to validate its stress-testing model by checking whether past losses exceeded projected stressed losses, but finds this impossible due to limited historical crises. What challenge is being demonstrated?

options.text: Stress tests cannot be back-tested like VaR due to scarce data on extreme events
Stress tests always require daily loss data
Stress tests fail unless correlations remain constant
Stress tests cannot incorporate multiple variables

questions.explanation: Stress testing deals with extreme, rare events that provide insufficient data for traditional back-testing.

questions.questionText: A bank’s stress test shows that a 20% decline in equity markets results in modest losses, but when GDP and unemployment shocks are added, losses become severe. What does this illustrate about scenario design?

options.text: Interactions between macro variables can materially amplify stress outcomes
GDP shocks do not affect financial institutions
Equity shocks are irrelevant in stress tests

questions.explanation: Macro variables interact, and combined stresses often produce nonlinear increases in losses.

questions.questionText: A bank chooses not to include a major cybersecurity threat in its stress scenarios because it has never experienced such an attack. Why is this a weakness?

options.text: Stress tests only cover market risk
Stress testing must consider emerging and non-historical threats
Cyber risk is excluded from Basel frameworks
Stress tests can only use past data

questions.explanation: Stress testing must consider new vulnerabilities that may not be represented in historical data.

questions.questionText: A bank conducts a stress test assuming a repeat of the 2007–2008 crisis but finds that its current mortgage portfolio is far riskier than before. Why might stressed VaR fail to capture the full severity of losses in this case?

options.text: Stressed VaR uses unlimited historical data
Stressed VaR applies a short horizon that may not reflect full-year economic deterioration
Stressed VaR always underestimates credit spreads
Stressed VaR is required to assume linear correlations

questions.explanation: Stressed VaR uses a short horizon (often 1–10 days) based on stressed data, while full stress tests capture multi-month worsening of the crisis.

questions.questionText: During a scenario workshop, senior leaders propose a scenario where commercial real estate prices fall 35%, but risk analysts dismiss it as unrealistic. Why should such scenarios still be considered?

options.text: Stress tests must use only scenarios with historical precedent
Stress testing aims to explore unlikely but plausible outcomes that may reveal vulnerabilities
Scenarios should reflect only market risk and not real estate markets
Regulators require all scenarios to be neutral, not adverse

questions.explanation: Stress testing is forward-looking and includes severe scenarios that may have no historical precedent but remain plausible.

questions.questionText: A bank evaluates a scenario where GDP declines moderately but liquidity markets freeze, leading to severe funding pressures. Which stress-testing issue does this illustrate?

options.text: Peripheral variables are irrelevant for liquidity modelling
Liquidity stresses can amplify losses even when credit shocks are modest
GDP declines always imply low liquidity risk
Liquidity shocks cannot be included in stress testing

questions.explanation: Liquidity effects often interact with credit and market variables, amplifying otherwise mild macro shocks.

questions.questionText: A bank sets its stress-testing horizon to one week to simplify modelling. Regulators argue this is inappropriate for credit portfolios. Why?

options.text: Credit risk only materializes within one day
Credit losses develop over longer horizons and require multi-month scenarios
Short horizons exaggerate credit migration effects
Regulations prohibit stress tests shorter than six months

questions.explanation: Credit deterioration occurs gradually; inadequate horizons may severely understate losses.

questions.questionText: In a reverse stress test, analysts conclude that the bank would fail only if unemployment rose to 25% and GDP declined by 12%. Management dismisses the outcome as impossible. What key purpose of reverse stress testing are they missing?

options.text: It is intended to forecast future economic recessions
It identifies thresholds where internal controls and capital buffers fail
It helps determine dividend payout ratios

questions.explanation: Reverse stress testing is not about forecasting but identifying breaking points where failure becomes possible.

questions.questionText: A bank's stress-testing model uses relationships between variables estimated during calm markets. But during a crisis, stress results appear unrealistic. What modelling flaw likely occurred?

options.text: Using core variables instead of peripheral variables
Failing to calibrate variable relationships using data from stressed periods

questions.explanation: Relationships between variables differ under stress—stressed-period calibration is essential.

questions.questionText: A bank notices that when interest rates rise 200 bps in a scenario, equity prices also fall sharply, despite historically weak correlations between the two. What effect is this most likely showing?
questions.explanation: Correlations generally increase during stressed markets, making diversification less effective.

questions.questionText: After completing a stress test, analysts observe significant losses in the trading book but modest losses in retail banking. Senior management concludes the scenario is irrelevant. What is the governance concern here?

options.text: Management must disregard outcomes that do not affect all units
Management should consider enterprise-wide implications, even if some units are less affected
Stress tests must show uniform losses across all segments
Scenario results should never influence strategic planning

questions.explanation: Risk concentrations in one division may threaten the firm as a whole; governance requires enterprise-wide interpretation.

questions.questionText: A bank uses ad hoc stress tests after a national referendum unexpectedly triggers financial market turmoil. Why are ad hoc tests appropriate here?

options.text: Ad hoc scenarios must replace all historical scenarios
Ad hoc tests capture new risks that historical data cannot reflect
Regulators require only ad hoc tests for market events
Ad hoc tests automatically validate model assumptions

questions.explanation: Ad hoc scenarios adapt to emerging risks with no historical precedent.

questions.questionText: A firm’s board approves a stress-testing framework but does not participate in scenario discussions or challenge assumptions. What key Basel principle is being violated?

options.text: Boards must design and implement stress tests themselves
Boards must be actively involved in setting objectives and challenging results
Boards must run internal audit activities

questions.explanation: Basel stresses active board engagement in scenario formulation and challenge.

questions.questionText: A global bank uses multiple vendor models for stress testing but does not document how those models operate. What governance issue arises?

options.text: Vendor models do not require validation
Model documentation is essential to allow independent review and continuity
Documentation is unnecessary if scenarios are historical

questions.explanation: Stress-testing policies require documentation for both internal and vendor models.

questions.questionText: A bank designs a scenario where interest rates rise sharply but fails to specify how peripheral variables like prepayment rates or credit spreads should respond. What modelling weakness does this reflect?

options.text: Failure to model peripheral variables linked to core assumptions

questions.explanation: Peripheral variables must be modelled consistently with core variable movements.

questions.questionText: After conducting several stress tests, a bank discards all results exceeding its risk appetite because management believes they represent tail events that are too unlikely. Why is this problematic?

options.text: Stress tests must forecast the most likely outcome
Stress tests should inform decision-making even for unlikely but severe scenarios
Stress tests should be ignored if loss forecasts are high
Stress tests should only consider benign scenarios

questions.explanation: Stress testing highlights extreme risks; ignoring them undermines risk management.

questions.questionText: A stress test shows that under a severe recession, the bank’s capital ratio falls sharply while its liquidity position remains strong. What should management conclude?

options.text: Capital and liquidity risks behave independently and must both be evaluated
Liquidity is irrelevant in stress scenarios
Capital risk can be ignored if liquidity is strong

questions.explanation: Stress testing examines both capital adequacy and liquidity—strength in one does not imply strength in the other.

questions.questionText: A large trading desk’s stress results vary widely each quarter because its exposures change rapidly. What stress-testing design choice might reduce volatility in results?

options.text: Fixing scenarios that reflect long-term macroeconomic risks
Avoiding portfolio updates during stress testing
Applying shorter horizons to smooth results

questions.explanation: Macro scenarios provide stability and consistency for portfolios with frequently changing positions.

questions.questionText: A bank incorporates a scenario with a 40% equity fall but fails to include second-round effects such as margin calls and liquidity hoarding. What is being overlooked?

options.text: Knock-on effects that exacerbate the initial shock

questions.explanation: Knock-on effects capture behavioral and market reactions that worsen the initial stress.

questions.questionText: CCAR requires banks to include an internal stress scenario in addition to baseline and severely adverse scenarios. What is the purpose of this internal scenario?

options.text: To ensure banks consider risks specific to their own portfolios
To eliminate the need for regulatory scenarios
To replace the severely adverse scenario when markets calm

questions.explanation: Internal scenarios capture institution-specific vulnerabilities that standardized scenarios may miss.

questions.questionText: A bank performs a stress test where the unemployment rate rises 5%. Analysts estimate loan losses using rating-agency default data linked to unemployment. What technique is being applied?

options.text: Peripheral variable estimation driven by macroeconomic core variables

questions.explanation: Loan losses depend on peripheral variables such as default rates, which are derived from core macro variables.

questions.questionText: A money market trader evaluates a 68-day U.S. Treasury bill quoted at 1.52%. The trader wants to determine the true purchase cost and discount factor before deciding whether to roll the position. Based on the quote, what is the bill’s cash price per USD 100 face value?
questions.explanation: Cash price = 100 − (Q × n / 360) = 100 − (1.52 × 68 / 360) = 99.7129. This reflects the money-market discount convention.

questions.questionText: A bond analyst prices a Treasury note quoted at 98.75 with settlement occurring 47 days after the last coupon date. The bond has a 4% annual coupon. Before executing a trade, the analyst wants the dirty price. What is the accrued interest per USD 100 face value?
questions.explanation: Accrued interest = c × t/T = 2.0 × (47/182) = 0.5165. Dirty price = 98.75 + 0.5165.

questions.questionText: A six-month bond with a 3.5% annual coupon trades at 100.8. A portfolio manager wants to extract the six-month discount factor for constructing a term structure. What is the discount factor implied by this price?

A risk analyst observes a six-month bond priced at 101.2 with a 4% coupon and a one-year bond priced at 102.5 with a 5% coupon. The analyst seeks the one-year discount factor for consistency checks in a bootstrapped curve. What is the resulting one-year discount factor?
questions.explanation: Using the six-month DF of 0.99216, price equation: 102.5 = 2.5×DF(0.5) + 102.5×DF(1). Solving gives DF(1) = 0.97580.

questions.questionText: A Treasury investor purchases a note quoted at 101.35. With 120 days accrued out of a 182-day coupon cycle and a 6% annual coupon, they want to determine the dirty price. What accrued interest (per USD 100 face value) should be added?
questions.explanation: Accrued interest = 3 × (120/182) = 1.9780.

questions.questionText: A corporate bond priced under a 30/360 convention accrues interest between April 12 and August 3 on a 10% annual coupon. A trader needs the number of interest-accruing days using 30/360 to value the position. What is the day count?
questions.explanation: 30/360 counts: Apr (18), May 30, Jun 30, Jul 30, Aug 3 → total = 111 days.

questions.questionText: An arbitrage desk evaluates a 91-day Treasury bill quoted at 1.25%. Before comparing it to repo rates, they compute the discount factor. What is the implied discount factor?
A fixed-income modeler values a one-year bond with semiannual coupons of 1.5. With a six-month discount factor of 0.99713 and price of 100.2, what is the implied one-year discount factor?

An investor holds a Treasury bond the day before its coupon date. The annual coupon is 6%, with 181 days between coupon dates. On day 181 since the prior coupon, what is the bond’s accrued interest per USD 100 face value?

A trader replicates a bond paying 103 at maturity using another bond paying 101.8125 at that date. They need the replication multiplier to match the terminal cash flow precisely. What is the required multiple?
questions.explanation: Required multiplier = 103 / 101.8125 = 1.01166.

questions.questionText: A T-bill trader compares two bills and finds one priced at 99.6840 for a 91-day maturity. They want to compute the annualized money-market yield implied by this price. Using the discount convention, what is the yield?
questions.explanation: The quote is itself the money-market yield over 360 days: Q = 1.25%.

questions.questionText: A pricing modeler studies the behavior of dirty prices as coupon dates approach. On day 181 of 182 for a 6% coupon bond, they compute the dirty price assuming a clean price of 100. What is the dirty price?

A portfolio manager reviews a Treasury note with a 4% coupon and 120/182 accrued days. Given a clean price of 101.35, they want to estimate the yield change effect by isolating clean vs dirty pricing. What is the dirty price?
questions.explanation: Dirty price = 101.35 + accrued (1.9780) = 103.33.

questions.questionText: A trader bootstrapping discount factors finds the six-month DF is 0.99216 and the one-year DF is 0.97580. They price a one-year zero-coupon bond using those implied rates. What is its price per USD 100 face value?

A dealer quotes a 52-day U.S. Treasury bill at 1.65%. Before deciding whether to lend excess cash through the bill, a money market fund manager wants the cash price and discount factor. What is the cash price per USD 100 face value implied by this quote?

A 91-day Treasury bill trades at a cash price of 99.745 per USD 100 face value. A trader wants to recover the quoted money-market discount rate Q to compare with other short-term funding options. What is the quoted rate (on a 360-day basis)?

A six-month bond with a 2.5% annual coupon (paid semiannually) is quoted at 99.80 per USD 100 face value. A risk analyst wants to extract the six-month discount factor from this price for bootstrapping purposes. What is the six-month discount factor?
questions.explanation: Semiannual coupon = 0.5×2.5%×100 = 1.25. For a 6-month bond, price = (100 + 1.25)×DF → DF = 99.80 / 101.25 ≈ 0.98568.

questions.questionText: Using the six-month discount factor you just estimated (≈0.98568), you observe a one-year bond with a 4% annual coupon (semiannual) trading at 101.00 per USD 100 face value. To complete your discount curve, you solve for the one-year discount factor. What is this one-year discount factor?

A two-year bond pays a 3% annual coupon with semiannual payments. A term structure analyst has estimated discount factors of 0.99, 0.98, 0.97, and 0.96 for maturities at 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 years, respectively. What is the theoretical price per USD 100 face value of this bond?

A six-month zero-coupon bond is priced at 99.30 per USD 100 face value. A one-year bond with a 3% annual coupon (semiannual) trades at 100.40. You wish to bootstrap the one-year discount factor. What is the implied one-year discount factor?

A U.S. Treasury bond with a 5% annual coupon pays semiannual coupons on January 15 and July 15. A trade settles on April 10, and the clean price is 102.40 per USD 100 face value. Under the actual/actual (in period) convention, what is the accrued interest per USD 100 face value as of settlement?
questions.explanation: Semiannual coupon = 0.5×5%×100 = 2.5. Days between coupon dates (Jan 15–Jul 15) = 90; days from last coupon to settlement (Jan 15–Apr 10) = 85. Accrued = 2.5×85/90 ≈ 2.3611.

questions.questionText: The same 5% bond is instead a corporate bond priced under the 30/360 convention, with coupons on January 15 and July 15 and settlement on April 10. A credit analyst wants to compare accrued interest under 30/360 versus Treasury actual/actual. Under 30/360, what is the accrued interest per USD 100 face value?
questions.explanation: 30/360 days from Jan 15 to Apr 10: (30−15) + 30 + 30 + 10 = 85 days. Semiannual 30/360 period = 180 days. Accrued = 2.5×85/180 ≈ 1.1806.

questions.questionText: A municipal bond uses the 30/360 day-count convention. An investor holds the bond from May 30 to June 1 within a coupon period and asks how many days of interest accrue over this interval under 30/360. What is the number of interest-accruing days?
questions.explanation: Under 30/360, May has 30 days. From May 30 to June 1: (30−30) + 1 = 1 day of interest.

questions.questionText: A money market fund purchases a 73-day instrument in the U.S. quoted at 3.2% on an actual/360 basis with a notional of USD 5 million. To estimate its return over the holding period, the fund calculates the interest earned. What is the interest over 73 days?

Given six-month and one-year discount factors of 0.99 and 0.975, respectively, a term structure analyst wants the implied six-month forward rate for the period from 0.5 to 1 year. What is the effective six-month forward rate for that period?
questions.explanation: Forward discount factor for 6 months = DF(1)/DF(0.5) = 0.975/0.99 ≈ 0.98485. The 6-month effective forward rate = 1/0.98485 − 1 ≈ 1.538% ≈ 1.54%.

questions.questionText: A 1-year Treasury bill is quoted at 2.40% using the money-market discount convention (360-day basis). A P-STRIP maturing on the same date trades at 97.30 per USD 100 face value. To check for arbitrage, a trader computes the discount factors. What is the discount factor implied by the P-STRIP price?
questions.explanation: The P-STRIP is a zero-coupon bond: DF = price/100 = 97.30/100 = 0.9730.

questions.questionText: A long-dated P-STRIP with face value USD 100 trades at 82.45. A fixed-income quant wants its discount factor to anchor the far end of the curve. What is the discount factor at that maturity?
questions.explanation: For a zero-coupon instrument, DF = price/face = 82.45 / 100 = 0.8245.

questions.questionText: A trader wants to replicate the final cash flow of a bond that pays USD 105 at maturity using another bond that pays USD 102.75 at that same date and has no other cash flows. To match the maturity cash flow exactly, what multiple of the second bond should the trader hold?
questions.explanation: Required multiple = 105 / 102.75 ≈ 1.02190.

questions.questionText: An investor buys a bond with a 4% annual coupon (semiannual) where there are 184 days between coupon payments. After holding the bond for 61 days since the last coupon, they sell it. Under actual/actual, what accrued interest per USD 100 face value is due to the seller at settlement?
questions.explanation: Semiannual coupon = 0.5×4%×100 = 2.0. Accrued interest = 2.0×(61/184) ≈ 0.6630.

questions.questionText: A pension fund invests USD 100 today in a three-year risk-free deposit paying 6% per annum with semi-annual compounding. Assuming the rate remains constant, what is the value of the deposit at maturity?
questions.explanation: With 6% per annum and semi-annual compounding, the six-month rate is 3%. Over three years there are 6 periods, so the future value is 100 × (1.03)^6 ≈ 100 × 1.19405 = USD 119.41.

questions.questionText: A bank offers a loan at 7% per annum with semi-annual compounding. What is the equivalent effective annual rate (EAR)?
The three-year spot rate is 4.5% per annum with semi-annual compounding. What is the three-year discount factor?
questions.explanation: With 4.5% and semi-annual compounding, each period rate is 2.25%. Over three years there are 6 periods, so the discount factor is 1 / (1.0225)^6 ≈ 0.87502.

questions.questionText: A five-year zero-coupon Treasury has a discount factor of 0.78 when spot rates are quoted with semi-annual compounding. What is the implied five-year spot rate (per annum, semi-annual compounding)?
questions.explanation: Let r be the annual spot rate with semi-annual compounding. For 10 periods, 0.78 = 1 / (1 + r/2)^10 ⇒ (1 + r/2)^10 = 1 / 0.78. Thus 1 + r/2 = (1/0.78)^(1/10) ≈ 1.02516, giving r = 2 × 0.02516 ≈ 5.03%.

questions.questionText: A pension plan expects to receive USD 100 in 8 years. The 8-year spot rate is 5% per annum with semi-annual compounding. What is the present value of this cash flow?
questions.explanation: With 5% and semi-annual compounding, the six-month rate is 2.5%. Over 8 years there are 16 periods. The discount factor is 1 / (1.025)^16 ≈ 0.67362, so the present value is 100 × 0.67362 ≈ USD 67.36.

questions.questionText: A bank quotes a deposit rate of 6% per annum with annual compounding. What is the equivalent rate with continuous compounding?
questions.explanation: For an annual rate R = 6%, the equivalent continuously compounded rate is Rc = ln(1 + R) = ln(1.06) ≈ 0.05827, or 5.83%.

questions.questionText: A corporate loan is priced at 5.5% per annum with continuous compounding. What is the equivalent nominal rate with quarterly compounding?
questions.explanation: Let Rc = 5.5% be the continuous rate. For quarterly compounding, Rq satisfies (1 + Rq/4)^4 = e^{Rc}. Thus Rq = 4(e^{Rc/4} − 1). Substituting Rc = 0.055 gives Rq ≈ 5.54%.

questions.questionText: The one-year and two-year spot rates (annual compounding) are 3% and 4%, respectively. What is the one-year forward rate for the period from year 1 to year 2 (annual compounding)?
questions.explanation: Let f be the one-year forward rate. Equate 2-year growth: (1.04)^2 = (1.03)(1 + f). Thus 1 + f = (1.04)^2 / 1.03 ≈ 1.05010, so f ≈ 5.01%.

questions.questionText: The two-year and five-year spot rates with continuous compounding are 3.2% and 4.1%, respectively. What is the implied continuously compounded forward rate for the period from year 2 to year 5?
questions.explanation: With continuous compounding, the forward rate F for [2,5] satisfies R5·5 = R2·2 + F·(5 − 2). Thus F = (R5·5 − R2·2)/3 = (0.041·5 − 0.032·2)/3 = 0.047, or 4.7%.

questions.questionText: Six-month and two-year spot rates (semi-annual compounding) are as follows: the 1.5-year spot rate is 3.6% and the 2-year spot rate is 3.8%. What is the six-month forward rate (per annum, semi-annual compounding) for the period from 1.5 years to 2.0 years?
questions.explanation: Let f be the six-month forward rate. With semi-annual compounding: (1 + 0.038/2)^4 = (1 + 0.036/2)^3 (1 + f). Solving gives 1 + f ≈ 1.02201, so f ≈ 2.20% per annum on a semi-annual basis.

questions.questionText: Discount factors for maturities 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 years are 0.98, 0.955, 0.93, and 0.90, respectively. Coupons are paid semi-annually. What is the two-year par rate (per annum)?

For a four-year bond with semi-annual coupons, the par rate is 5% and the annuity value A(4) (sum of discount factors for each coupon date) is 3.70. The four-year discount factor d(4) is 0.89. What is the price of a four-year bond with the same maturity and face value 100 but a coupon rate of 3% per annum?
questions.explanation: The 3% coupon bond pays 1.5 every six months. Its price is PV of coupons plus principal: 1.5 × A(4) + 100·d(4) = 1.5 × 3.70 + 89 = 5.55 + 89 = USD 94.55.

questions.questionText: Spot rates (per annum, semi-annual compounding) are 3.0% for 0.5 years, 3.4% for 1.0 year, and 3.8% for 1.5 years. What is the six-month forward rate (per annum, semi-annual compounding) for the period from year 1.0 to year 1.5?
questions.explanation: Compute discount factors: d(1.0) = 1 / (1.017)^2 ≈ 0.96685 and d(1.5) = 1 / (1.019)^3 ≈ 0.94510. The six-month forward rate f satisfies (1 + f/2) = d(1.0)/d(1.5), so f/2 ≈ 0.02301 and f ≈ 4.60%.

questions.questionText: A zero-coupon bond pays USD 100 in 2.5 years. The continuously compounded spot rate for 2.5 years is 4.6%. What is the current price of the bond?
questions.explanation: With continuous compounding, the present value is 100·e^{−0.046×2.5} ≈ 100·e^{−0.115} ≈ 100 × 0.89137 = USD 89.14.

questions.questionText: A three-year corporate bond is priced using a flat continuously compounded spot rate of 4.6%. What is the equivalent annual spot rate with semi-annual compounding?
questions.explanation: Let Rc = 4.6%. The equivalent semi-annual rate R satisfies (1 + R/2)^2 = e^{Rc}, so R = 2(e^{Rc/2} − 1). With Rc = 0.046, this gives R ≈ 4.65%.

questions.questionText: Discount factors for 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 years are 0.97, 0.94, and 0.90, respectively. Coupons are paid semi-annually. What is the 1.5-year par rate (per annum)?

Using the discount factors in the previous question (0.97, 0.94, 0.90) and the par rate of 7.12%, what is the price of a 1.5-year bond with the same maturity and face value 100 but a coupon rate of 5% per annum, paid semi-annually?
questions.explanation: The 5% coupon bond pays 2.5 every six months. Its price is 2.5(0.97 + 0.94 + 0.90) + 100·0.90 = 2.5 × 2.81 + 90 = 7.025 + 90 ≈ USD 99.97.

questions.questionText: The three-year and five-year spot rates (per annum, semi-annual compounding) are 4.0% and 4.6%, respectively. What is the implied two-year forward rate (per annum, semi-annual compounding) for the period from year 3 to year 5?
questions.explanation: With semi-annual compounding, the discount factors are d(3) = 1 / (1.02)^6 ≈ 0.88797 and d(5) = 1 / (1.023)^10 ≈ 0.79661. The two-year forward rate f satisfies d(5) = d(3)/(1 + f/2)^4. Solving gives (1 + f/2)^4 = d(3)/d(5) ≈ 1.1146, so f/2 ≈ 0.02752 and f ≈ 5.50%.

questions.questionText: A three-month money market instrument in USD is quoted at 3.2% on an actual/360 basis for a 90-day term. What is the corresponding effective annual rate (EAR), assuming reinvestment at the same 90-day rate?
questions.explanation: The simple return over 90 days is i_90 = 0.032 × 90/360 = 0.008. The effective annual rate is (1 + i_90)^{365/90} − 1 ≈ 1.008^{4.0556} − 1 ≈ 3.28%.

questions.questionText: A three-year zero-coupon bond is priced using a continuously compounded spot rate of 2.8% per annum. What is the current price of a bond that pays USD 100 at maturity?
questions.explanation: With continuous compounding, the price is 100·e^{−0.028×3} = 100·e^{−0.084} ≈ 100 × 0.91943 = USD 91.94.

questions.questionText: A treasury analyst compares two loan offers for a one-year USD facility. Bank A quotes 9.0% per annum with annual compounding, while Bank B quotes a nominal rate with quarterly compounding that leads to the same value after one year. What nominal annual rate with quarterly compounding is equivalent to 9.0% with annual compounding?
questions.explanation: Set 1.09 = (1 + r/4)^4 and solve for r. This gives r = 4[(1.09)^(1/4) − 1] ≈ 0.0871, so the equivalent nominal rate with quarterly compounding is about 8.71% per annum.

questions.questionText: A pension fund expects to receive a single USD 200 contribution in 7 years and discounts liabilities at 6.0% per annum with semi-annual compounding. What is the present value today of this future contribution?
questions.explanation: With semi-annual compounding, the periodic rate is 6.0%/2 = 3.0% and there are 14 periods in 7 years. The present value is 200 / (1.03)^14 ≈ USD 132.22.

questions.questionText: A zero-coupon bond maturing in 4 years is priced to imply a discount factor of 0.89 for that maturity. Assuming semi-annual compounding, what is the implied 4-year spot rate per annum?
questions.explanation: With semi-annual compounding, 0.89 = 1 / (1 + r/2)^8. Solving gives (1 + r/2) = (1/0.89)^(1/8), so r = 2[(1/0.89)^(1/8) − 1] ≈ 2.93% per annum.

questions.questionText: A dealer observes that the 1-year USD spot rate is 2.5% and the 3-year USD spot rate is 3.4%, both quoted with continuous compounding. What is the implied continuously compounded forward rate between years 1 and 3?
questions.explanation: For continuous compounding, the forward rate between T1 and T2 is F = (R2 T2 − R1 T1)/(T2 − T1). Here F = (0.034×3 − 0.025×1)/2 ≈ 0.0385, i.e., about 3.85% per annum.

questions.questionText: The six-month and nine-month USD spot rates are 3.0% and 3.4% per annum, respectively, quoted with semi-annual compounding. What is the implied six-month forward rate per annum for the period from 1.0 to 1.5 years, expressed with semi-annual compounding?
questions.explanation: Let R1 = 3.0% and R2 = 3.4% with semi-annual compounding. The six-month forward per half-year is f = (1 + R2/2)^3 / (1 + R1/2)^2 − 1 ≈ 0.0210. Annualizing gives 2f ≈ 4.20% per annum.

questions.questionText: A risk manager bootstraps discount factors from Treasury prices and estimates d(0.5) = 0.99, d(1.0) = 0.975, d(1.5) = 0.960, and d(2.0) = 0.940. Assuming coupons are paid every six months, what is the 2-year par rate per annum implied by these discount factors?
questions.explanation: Let A(2) = 0.99 + 0.975 + 0.960 + 0.940 = 3.865. From the par-rate formula p = 2(1 − d(T))/A(T), p = 2(1 − 0.94)/3.865 ≈ 0.0310, so the 2-year par rate is about 3.10% per annum.

questions.questionText: Using the same discount factors d(0.5) = 0.99, d(1.0) = 0.975, d(1.5) = 0.960, and d(2.0) = 0.940, a trader values a 2-year government bond with a coupon of 5.0% per annum paid semi-annually and face value of USD 100. What is the model price of the bond?
A treasurer discounts a 4-year deterministic liability stream using a flat 4.6% spot rate quoted with semi-annual compounding. What is the 4-year discount factor implied by this rate?
questions.explanation: With semi-annual compounding, the discount factor is d(4) = 1 / (1 + 0.046/2)^8. This yields d(4) ≈ 1 / (1.023)^8 ≈ 0.8337.

questions.questionText: A bank quotes a nominal lending rate of 7.0% per annum with quarterly compounding, but a derivatives desk prefers to work with continuously compounded rates. What continuously compounded rate is equivalent to 7.0% with quarterly compounding?
questions.explanation: Equate (1 + 0.07/4)^4 to e^{Rc}. Thus Rc = 4 ln(1 + 0.07/4) ≈ 0.0694, so the equivalent continuously compounded rate is about 6.94% per annum.

questions.questionText: A risk-free term structure is quoted with a continuously compounded rate of 6.2% per annum for all maturities. A bond analyst wants the equivalent rate with semi-annual compounding. What nominal annual rate with semi-annual compounding matches 6.2% with continuous compounding?
questions.explanation: For continuous-to-m compounding, Rm = m(e^{Rc/m} − 1). With Rc = 0.062 and m = 2, Rm = 2(e^{0.062/2} − 1) ≈ 0.0630, i.e., 6.30% per annum with semi-annual compounding.

questions.questionText: An investor pays USD 100 today for a zero-coupon bond that returns USD 112 in 3 years with annual compounding. What is the implied annual interest rate on this investment?
questions.explanation: With annual compounding, 112 = 100(1 + R)^3. Thus R = (112/100)^{1/3} − 1 ≈ 0.0385, or about 3.85% per annum.

questions.questionText: A liability of USD 100 is due in 10 years. The risk-free yield curve is flat at 5.5% per annum with continuous compounding. What is the present value of this liability today?
questions.explanation: Under continuous compounding, the discount factor is e^{−rT}. The present value is 100 e^{−0.055×10} ≈ 100 e^{−0.55} ≈ USD 57.69.

questions.questionText: The 3-year USD spot rate is 4.0% per annum with continuous compounding. What is (i) the 3-year discount factor and (ii) the price today of a 3-year zero-coupon bond with face value USD 1,000?
questions.explanation: With continuous compounding, d(3) = e^{−0.04×3} ≈ 0.8869. The zero-coupon price is 1,000×d(3) ≈ USD 886.92.

questions.questionText: Six-month and one-year USD spot rates are 2.2% and 2.6% per annum, respectively, both quoted with semi-annual compounding. What is the implied six-month forward rate per annum for the period from 0.5 to 1.0 years?
questions.explanation: Let R0.5 = 2.2% and R1 = 2.6%. The forward per half-year is f = (1 + R1/2)^2 / (1 + R0.5/2) − 1 ≈ 0.0150. Annualizing gives 2f ≈ 3.00% per annum.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager uses discount factors d(0.5) = 0.99, d(1.0) = 0.975, d(1.5) = 0.955, and d(2.0) = 0.930 to value a 2-year bond with a 4.0% annual coupon (semi-annual payments) and face value USD 100. What is the model price of this bond?

Using the same discount factors d(0.5) = 0.99, d(1.0) = 0.975, d(1.5) = 0.955, and d(2.0) = 0.930, the risk team wants the 2-year par rate per annum. What par rate is implied by these discount factors (semi-annual payments)?
questions.explanation: The annuity factor is A(2) = 0.99 + 0.975 + 0.955 + 0.93 = 3.85. The par rate satisfies p = 2(1 − d(T))/A(T), so p = 2(1 − 0.93)/3.85 ≈ 0.0364, or about 3.64% per annum.

questions.questionText: A trader is given that the six-month discount factor is 0.97. Assuming semi-annual compounding, what is the implied 6-month spot rate per annum?
questions.explanation: For a 0.5-year maturity with semi-annual compounding, d(0.5) = 1/(1 + R/2). Thus 0.97 = 1/(1 + R/2), giving R/2 = 1/0.97 − 1 ≈ 0.03093, so R ≈ 6.19% per annum.

questions.questionText: The 2-year and 5-year USD spot rates are 3.2% and 4.0% per annum, respectively, quoted with continuous compounding. What is the implied continuously compounded forward rate between years 2 and 5?
questions.explanation: With continuous compounding, F(2,5) = (R5×5 − R2×2)/(5 − 2) = (0.04×5 − 0.032×2)/3 ≈ 0.0453, i.e., about 4.53% per annum.

questions.questionText: A term structure is quoted with 2-year and 3-year spot rates of 3.1% and 3.6% per annum, respectively, both with continuous compounding. What is the implied continuously compounded 1-year forward rate for the period from year 2 to year 3?
questions.explanation: The forward rate between 2 and 3 years is F = (R3×3 − R2×2)/(3 − 2) = (0.036×3 − 0.031×2)/1 ≈ 0.046, or about 4.60% per annum with continuous compounding.

questions.questionText: An investor buys a bond for USD 97 immediately after a coupon date. The bond pays a semi-annual coupon of USD 2.0 and is worth USD 98.4 six months later. What is the gross realized six-month return?
questions.explanation: The gross return is (98.4 − 97 + 2.0) / 97 = 3.44%.

questions.questionText: A bond purchased at USD 102 receives a coupon of USD 1.75 at six months, reinvested at 1.2% for the next six months. The bond’s value after one year is USD 103.2. What is the investor’s gross annual realized return?

An investor finances a USD 100 bond purchase at 3.2% (semi-annual compounding). The financing cost over six months is USD 1.60. If the gross six-month return on the bond is USD 3.10, what is the net realized return?
questions.explanation: Net return = (3.10 − 1.60) / 100 = 1.50%, annualized to 0.90% over six months.

questions.questionText: A two-year Treasury forward curve shows six-month forward rates of 0.8%, 1.3%, 1.7%, and 2.1% (semi-annual compounding). What is the 18-month discount factor?
A two-year bond with a 3% coupon is priced at USD 101.8. Using discount factors of 0.995, 0.987, 0.979, and 0.969, what is the bond’s theoretical value?
If a bond’s theoretical value is USD 102.4 but it is purchased at USD 101.6, which spread added to all forwards equates PV to the traded price?
questions.explanation: The spread that reduces PV from 102.4 to 101.6 is approximately 35 bps annually.

questions.questionText: A three-year bond with a coupon of 4% sells for USD 103.2. Using semi-annual compounding, what is the approximate yield-to-maturity?
questions.explanation: Solving the YTM equation yields approximately 3.38% with semi-annual compounding.

questions.questionText: A perpetuity pays USD 4 annually, with coupons every six months. If the yield is 5% (semi-annual compounding), what is its value?
questions.explanation: Value = coupon / yield = 4 / 0.05 = 80 under simple annualization; semi-annual basis gives 4 / (0.0525) ≈ 76.19.

questions.questionText: A five-year bond paying 5% sells for USD 104.5 when the curve is flat at 4%. If the curve stays unchanged in six months, the bond will be worth USD 104.1. What is the carry roll-down?
questions.explanation: Carry roll-down = coupon 2.5 − price change 0.41 ≈ 2.09.

questions.questionText: A portfolio valued at USD 102.2 earns the six-month forward rate of 0.7% (semi-annual compounding). Under the realized-forward assumption, what is the expected six-month carry?
A bond’s yield is unchanged at 6% over the next period. What is the expected gross return under the unchanged-yield assumption?
questions.explanation: Under unchanged-yield assumptions, the expected return equals the yield itself.

questions.questionText: In a downward-sloping curve, a five-year bond with higher coupons typically exhibits which YTM behavior relative to a low-coupon bond?
questions.explanation: With a downward-sloping curve, earlier discounted cash flows dominate, increasing YTM for higher-coupon bonds.

questions.questionText: A two-year bond is purchased for USD 101.4. If carry roll-down is USD 0.50, rate changes contribute USD 0.32, and spread changes contribute USD 0.08, what is the total P&L?
A five-year corporate bond offers 60 bps spread over Treasuries. If Treasury forwards shift up uniformly by 10 bps, what is the effect on the bond’s spread?
questions.explanation: A parallel shift in the Treasury curve does not change the credit spread.

questions.questionText: A bond pays USD 3 semi-annually for 10 years. At a yield of 6% (semi-annual compounding), what is the annuity value of these payments?
questions.explanation: Annuity factor = [1 − (1.03)^{-20}] / 0.03; multiplied by 3 gives ≈ 43.29.

questions.questionText: A zero-coupon bond maturing in three years is priced at USD 86.5. What is its YTM under semi-annual compounding?
A seven-year bond with a 6% coupon trades at USD 107. If the coupon rate exceeds YTM, how does the bond price behave over time assuming yields remain constant?

options.text: It fluctuates randomly around its yield

questions.explanation: When coupon exceeds YTM, the bond trades above par and gradually converges downward to par.

questions.questionText: A five-year bond currently worth USD 102.3 earns a one-period return equal to the six-month spot rate of 1.1%. What is the projected carry under realized-forward assumptions?
An investor expects realized rates to be lower than the forward curve. Which maturity strategy is preferred for higher expected gross returns?
questions.explanation: If realized rates fall below forwards, long-maturity bonds outperform due to greater duration exposure.

questions.questionText: An investor buys a bond at 98 and sells it six months later at 99 while reinvesting the coupon at a below-expected short-term rate. To accurately compute the realized return for the holding period, what must the investor include in the calculation?

options.text: Only the bond’s initial and final prices
Both reinvestment income and price appreciation
Only the reinvestment rate without cash flows

questions.explanation: Realized return incorporates all cash flows including coupon reinvestment and capital gains. Ignoring reinvestment understates performance.

questions.questionText: A trader buys a two-year Treasury at a price lower than the theoretical value implied by forward-rate discounting. She computes a uniform spread added to forward rates that equates discounted cash flows to the purchase price. What does this spread represent?

options.text: Credit compensation embedded in the Treasury curve
The excess return from acquiring the bond below fair value
Differences between spot and forward rates

questions.explanation: The spread represents the extra return earned because the bond was purchased at a discount to its theoretical no-arbitrage price.

questions.questionText: A bond trades between coupon dates and an analyst wants to compute its yield-to-maturity. Why must the dirty price be used rather than the quoted clean price?

options.text: Clean prices already include reinvestment assumptions
The dirty price reflects the actual cash outlay used when applying discounting
Accrued interest is irrelevant to YTM calculations
YTM is based only on par value and coupon rate

questions.explanation: YTM equates the PV of cash flows to the actual amount paid by the investor, which is the dirty price including accrued interest.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates two five-year bonds: a zero-coupon and a high-coupon bond. In an upward-sloping term structure, she finds that the high-coupon bond has a lower YTM. What explains this relationship?

options.text: Higher coupons always result in lower yields
Higher coupons shift cash flows earlier, benefiting from lower short-term spot rates
Zero-coupon bonds always have higher yields
The coupon effect does not apply when the curve slopes upward

questions.explanation: Under an upward-sloping curve, earlier payments are discounted at lower rates. Higher-coupon bonds therefore have lower YTMs.

questions.questionText: A premium bond with a 5% coupon sees its price fall over six months despite no change in interest rates. Why does this occur?

options.text: Premium bonds naturally move toward par over time when yields are unchanged
The reinvestment of coupons lowered the yield
Accrued interest reduces the clean price

questions.explanation: With stable yields, premium bonds amortize toward par as maturity approaches, decreasing the price even without rate movements.

questions.questionText: An analyst values a perpetuity that pays 4% annually with semiannual compounding. Why can the perpetuity formula be applied directly?

options.text: All cash flows occur at maturity
Discount factors approach zero at long maturities
Only the final cash flow matters

questions.explanation: In a perpetuity, extremely distant payments contribute negligibly to value because discount factors converge to zero.

questions.questionText: A trader observes that a bond’s gross return is significantly higher than its net return even though the bond price appreciated. What explains this difference?

options.text: Financing costs reduce net return relative to gross return

questions.explanation: Net returns subtract financing costs. Even strong price performance may be offset by borrowing costs incurred in funding the position.

questions.questionText: A fixed-income manager assumes forward rates will be realized and holds a bond for six months. The six-month forward rate is 0.7% (semiannual basis). What return should she expect?

options.text: The prevailing short-term rate applied to the bond’s current value
Only coupon income with no price change
The difference between YTM and the forward rate

questions.explanation: Under forward-rate realization, all bonds earn the short-term rate for the horizon regardless of coupon or maturity.

questions.questionText: An investor expects future realized rates to be lower than the forward curve suggests. She must choose between holding a long-maturity bond or rolling short-term instruments. Which strategy is likely superior?
questions.explanation: If realized rates fall below forwards, locking in the long-term yield provides a better return than rolling short maturities.

questions.questionText: A premium bond’s YTM decreases slightly over six months even though the term structure remains unchanged. What assumption leads to this outcome?

options.text: The term structure remains unchanged while the bond ages

questions.explanation: With an unchanged curve, yields adjust mechanically as maturity shortens, causing the YTM of coupon-bearing bonds to drift over time.

questions.questionText: A bond’s P&L shows that most of the gain came from the bond trading closer to its theoretical price, not from interest rate changes. Which P&L component captures this effect?
questions.explanation: Spread change reflects movements in a bond’s relative price versus theoretical value, independent of rate moves.

questions.questionText: A trader assumed forward rates would be realized but later observes rates shifted unexpectedly while spreads remained unchanged. The actual bond price differs from the predicted one. Which P&L term explains this?
questions.explanation: The rate change component captures deviations in price caused by unexpected shifts in the term structure compared with forward-rate expectations.

questions.questionText: A dealer values a Japanese bond and notes that its yield is computed differently than U.S. Treasuries. Which market convention explains this?

options.text: Japanese bonds do not accrue interest between coupons
Japanese yields are quoted on a simple-interest basis without compounding
Coupon payments are annual instead of semiannual

questions.explanation: Japan uses simple-interest yield conventions, which contrasts with compounded Treasury yields in the U.S. market.

questions.questionText: An investor neglects to include a coupon payment when evaluating the return on a bond position. How does this omission affect the calculated realized return?
questions.explanation: Coupons are a significant part of fixed-income returns. Excluding them results in understating total return.

questions.questionText: During a holding period, a bond’s credit spread widens while interest rates remain unchanged. What effect will this have on the bond’s value?

options.text: The bond’s price will fall because wider spreads increase discount rates
The bond’s price will remain unchanged
The bond’s value depends only on forward-rate changes

questions.explanation: Wider spreads imply higher discount rates, lowering the bond’s theoretical and actual market value.

questions.questionText: An analyst notices that a small increase in price results in a disproportionately large change in a short-term bond’s yield-to-maturity. What characteristic of YTM explains this?

options.text: YTM is a nonlinear function when converting price to yield
YTM equals the long-term spot rate
Yield depends only on coupon rate in short horizons

questions.explanation: The price–yield relationship is nonlinear, making yield highly sensitive to even small price changes—especially for short maturities.

questions.questionText: A firm analyzes a high-coupon bond under a downward-sloping yield curve. It finds that the bond’s YTM is higher than that of similar low-coupon bonds. What explains this?

options.text: High coupons reduce PV and increase yield
Early cash flows face higher short-term spot rates under a downward curve
YTM is independent of coupon size

questions.explanation: With a downward-sloping curve, early spot rates exceed long-term ones. High coupons emphasize early cash flows, increasing YTM.

questions.questionText: A trader observes that accrued interest increased significantly over a holding period although yields were stable. What impact does this have on P&L decomposition?

options.text: Accrued interest must be treated as a separate P&L component
Accrued interest is ignored in P&L calculations
Accrued interest is classified under spread changes
Accrued interest is included within rate changes

questions.explanation: Accrued interest changes are tracked separately from spread and rate effects when evaluating changes in a bond’s total value.

questions.questionText: A trader evaluates whether a bond’s repricing over a six-month horizon was driven by spread changes rather than rate changes. Which comparison best isolates the spread component?

options.text: Comparing actual price to the price under unchanged yields
Comparing actual price to the price using realized rates but constant spreads
Comparing clean and dirty prices over time

questions.explanation: Holding rates constant while allowing spreads to vary isolates the pure effect of spread movement relative to theoretical valuation.

questions.questionText: A pension fund holds a large position in long-dated government bonds. Management notices that recent parallel shifts in the yield curve have caused greater price swings than expected. They decide to compute DV01 to better monitor exposure. What does the DV01 measure for this bond portfolio?

options.text: Percentage change in price for a 1% yield shift
Dollar change in price for a one-basis-point parallel shift in all spot rates
The slope of the price-yield curve at zero yield
Expected price change for a non-parallel steepening of the curve

questions.explanation: DV01 represents the dollar value change of a position for a one-basis-point parallel shift in all spot rates.

questions.questionText: A hedge fund is analyzing a callable 7-year corporate bond whose probability of being called falls sharply when rates rise. When estimating effective duration, which factor must be incorporated into the price calculations after rate shocks?

options.text: A constant call probability regardless of rate changes
Only the Macaulay duration of a comparable non-callable bond
The change in call probability when rates rise or fall
Only the change in the bond’s coupon reinvestment rate

questions.explanation: Callable bond duration must incorporate how rate movements affect call likelihood; using a fixed probability is incorrect.

questions.questionText: A bank is exposed to a fixed-rate loan portfolio worth USD 500 million with an effective duration of 6.0. If the bank wants to hedge duration exposure using a Treasury bond with duration 5.0, what is the intended effect of establishing the appropriate hedge position?

options.text: Eliminate exposure to non-parallel yield curve shifts
Offset the portfolio’s price sensitivity to small parallel rate moves
Reduce DV01 to zero while increasing portfolio convexity
Fully immunize the portfolio against credit spread widening

questions.explanation: Duration hedging offsets the price impact from small parallel shifts in the term structure.

questions.questionText: A trader is comparing DV01 and effective duration for a bond. The bond’s price rises from USD 102 to 102.20 when yields drop 1 bp and falls to 101.80 when yields rise 1 bp. Why might effective duration be preferred over DV01 in this analysis?

options.text: Effective duration assesses percentage, not dollar, price sensitivity
DV01 cannot be used for any coupon-bearing bonds
Effective duration always equals modified duration
DV01 does not capture the impact of parallel shifts in rates

questions.explanation: DV01 measures dollar sensitivity; duration expresses sensitivity as a percentage change, aligning with return analysis.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager observes that the price-yield relationship for a bond is significantly curved, and duration alone underestimates the bond’s price increase when yields fall. Which feature of the bond explains this behavior?
questions.explanation: Positive convexity means price increases more when yields fall and decreases less when yields rise, relative to duration’s linear prediction.

questions.questionText: A firm estimates the convexity of a bond by revaluing it under +10 bp and –10 bp rate shocks. They notice the duration-only estimate of price change deviates noticeably from actual price changes under these shocks. What is convexity capturing in this context?

options.text: The average maturity of the bond’s cash flows
The linear sensitivity to rate changes
The curvature of the price-yield relationship
The likelihood of credit rating migration

questions.explanation: Convexity measures the second-order sensitivity—the curvature—of the bond price relative to interest rate changes.

questions.questionText: A bank models rate changes using a one-factor model. When the 2-year rate moves by 3 bps, the model automatically predicts movements at all maturities, though not all shifts are parallel. What property of a one-factor model does this demonstrate?

options.text: Forward rates adjust randomly without structure
The entire term structure is driven by a single underlying factor
Only short-term rates are affected by factor shocks

questions.explanation: One-factor models determine the movement of all rates from the movement of a single rate over a short horizon.

questions.questionText: An insurance company holds a puttable bond. When interest rates fall, the issuer’s refinancing cost declines. How does this affect the put option component and the bond’s effective duration?
questions.explanation: Lower rates favor exercising the put (bondholder gains), increasing put probability; this reduces effective duration.

questions.questionText: A fixed-income desk wants to immunize a USD 50 million position with duration 3.5 using a bond with duration 5.0. What does achieving a net duration of zero accomplish?

options.text: Fully immunizes the portfolio against parallel rate shifts
Eliminates exposure to volatility in short-term yields only

questions.explanation: A duration-neutral hedge removes first-order exposure to parallel shifts in the yield curve.

questions.questionText: A portfolio manager calculates portfolio DV01 as the sum of individual bond DV01s. Why is this aggregation valid?

options.text: DV01 is linear with respect to position size
DV01 accounts for non-parallel rate shifts
DV01 is the same across all maturities
DV01 ignores coupon structure, simplifying aggregation

questions.explanation: DV01 scales linearly with dollar exposure, allowing straightforward summation across instruments.

questions.questionText: A trader uses a duration-plus-convexity hedge rather than a pure duration hedge. Under what situation is this enhanced hedge particularly beneficial?

options.text: When rate changes are extremely small
When yield curve shifts are expected to be large and parallel
When non-parallel shifts dominate market movements
When hedging short-term money market instruments

questions.explanation: Adding convexity improves hedge accuracy for larger parallel shifts where duration’s linear approximation breaks down.

questions.questionText: A firm constructs a barbell portfolio using short- and long-maturity bonds to match the duration of a 10-year bullet bond. What is one disadvantage of the barbell strategy?

options.text: Lower convexity compared to the bullet bond
Poorer performance under non-parallel yield curve shifts
Lower yield when the curve is upward sloping
Greater reinvestment risk compared to the bullet bond

questions.explanation: Barbells often outperform bullets under parallel shifts due to higher convexity but may underperform under non-parallel shifts.

questions.questionText: A trader estimates effective duration by shocking all spot rates by ±5 bps. Which assumption underlies this calculation?

options.text: All yields move independently across maturities
Only the long-term rates shift when the short-term rate moves
The term structure experiences a parallel shift
Forward rates are unaffected by spot rate shocks

questions.explanation: Effective duration assumes a parallel shift in all spot rates to estimate the bond’s sensitivity.

questions.questionText: A bank compares modified duration and effective duration for a newly issued Treasury note. Under what market condition will these two measures align most closely?

options.text: When the yield curve shifts are parallel and small
When the note contains embedded call features
When the term structure is highly volatile

questions.explanation: Modified and effective duration converge when yield-based and spot-rate-based changes behave similarly under small parallel shifts.

questions.questionText: A portfolio contains bonds with durations of 3, 7, and 10 years and market values of 2m, 5m, and 3m respectively. The manager computes the weighted duration to understand rate sensitivity. What does this portfolio duration represent?

options.text: The average time to receive all coupon payments
Total dollar loss for a one-basis-point rate drop
The portfolio’s percentage price sensitivity to small parallel rate shifts
The minimum maturity required to immunize reinvestment risk

questions.explanation: Portfolio duration is the weighted average duration, expressing the percentage price change for small parallel rate changes.

questions.questionText: A trader recognizes that a long-dated bond exhibits significant curvature in its price response to yield changes. Why does duration alone become less reliable as yield shifts grow larger?

options.text: Duration captures only first-order effects and ignores curvature
Duration overestimates price increases and underestimates decreases
Duration models cash flows as constant regardless of rate shocks

questions.explanation: Duration is a linear approximation; convexity is required to capture second-order curvature for larger shifts.

questions.questionText: A hedge fund models DV01 for a position involving swaps and Treasury bonds. Why is DV01 more appropriate than duration for interest rate swaps?

options.text: Swap values are typically close to zero, making percentage-based duration meaningless
DV01 ignores changes in spot rates
Duration cannot be applied to derivative instruments

questions.explanation: Duration expresses percentage price change; swaps have near-zero market value, so DV01’s dollar-based measure is more meaningful.

questions.questionText: A firm constructs a hedge using two bonds so that both duration and convexity of the combined position are zero. What does this hedging approach protect against?

options.text: All interest rate movements, including non-parallel shifts
Small and moderately large parallel shifts in rates
Only changes in the 10-year benchmark rate
Spread widening and liquidity risk shocks

questions.explanation: Setting both duration and convexity to zero hedges against first- and second-order effects of parallel shifts but not non-parallel shifts.

questions.questionText: An asset manager argues that a barbell portfolio dominates a bullet portfolio because it has higher convexity for the same duration. Under what market condition might this claim fail?

options.text: When the term structure is flat and remains unchanged
When the yield curve shift is non-parallel
When interest rate volatility is extremely high

questions.explanation: Barbells outperform bullets under parallel shifts due to convexity advantages but may underperform under non-parallel shifts.

questions.questionText: A bank holds a portfolio of callable municipal bonds. After rates rise by 25 bps, the treasury team notes that the expected call probability has fallen sharply. How does this change affect the portfolio’s interest rate sensitivity?

options.text: Effective duration increases because the call option becomes less valuable
Effective duration decreases because the call option becomes more valuable
Effective duration is unaffected because the coupon rate remains unchanged
DV01 decreases because price volatility drops when rates rise

questions.explanation: As call probability declines, the bond behaves more like a non-callable bond, increasing its effective duration.

questions.questionText: A risk manager models DV01 for a swap book and observes that the DV01 increases proportionally as notional exposures rise. Which property of DV01 explains this behavior?

options.text: DV01 is invariant to the size of the position
DV01 scales linearly with notional size
DV01 depends solely on swap maturity and not on notional

questions.explanation: DV01 measures absolute dollar sensitivity and therefore increases directly with position size.

questions.questionText: Following a sharp drop in yields, a bond’s actual price increase exceeds what duration predicted. The analyst attributes the difference to convexity. Why does convexity cause this deviation?

options.text: Convexity reduces the impact of rate decreases
Convexity captures second-order effects that amplify price gains when yields fall
Convexity eliminates the need to calculate DV01
Convexity only applies when yields rise, not when they fall

questions.explanation: Positive convexity makes price increases larger than duration alone predicts when yields fall.

questions.questionText: A dealer is hedging a portfolio using duration matching. After implementing the hedge, the dealer notices that large rate movements still cause unexpected P/L swings. What explains this residual exposure?

options.text: Duration hedging only neutralizes first-order sensitivity
DV01 hedges always eliminate second-order risk
The yield curve moved in a perfectly parallel fashion

questions.explanation: Duration ignores convexity; large shifts expose the portfolio to curvature (second-order) effects.

questions.questionText: A credit union holds a portfolio of fixed-rate mortgages. It notes that when rates fall, duration shortens due to faster expected prepayments. Which type of convexity is the mortgage portfolio exhibiting?
questions.explanation: Mortgage-backed securities typically show negative convexity as falling rates lead to faster prepayments.

questions.questionText: An analyst compares two bonds: Bond A has higher duration but lower DV01 than Bond B. What most likely explains this observation?

options.text: Bond A has a higher price than Bond B
Bond A has lower convexity than Bond B
Bond A must be callable while Bond B is not
Bond A offers superior yield for the same maturity

questions.explanation: DV01 = Duration × Price × 0.0001; a higher-priced bond will have a larger DV01 for the same duration.

questions.questionText: During a stress test, a bank examines a scenario where long-term rates fall more than short-term rates. Under a one-factor non-parallel model, what does this imply?

options.text: Only the short end of the curve responds to the factor
The factor shock causes a twist in the yield curve
Spot rates move equally across all maturities
Convexity remains unaffected by the shock

questions.explanation: Some one-factor models produce non-parallel movements in yields (e.g., twists) while still being driven by one factor.

questions.questionText: A pension fund performs duration matching but still experiences losses when short-term rates rise while long-term rates fall. What type of risk remained unhedged?
questions.explanation: Duration hedging neutralizes only parallel shifts; non-parallel changes like twists still affect the portfolio.

questions.questionText: A corporate treasurer uses convexity-adjusted duration to estimate the bond’s value change following a 50 bp rate decrease. Why is the convexity adjustment particularly important here?

options.text: Large shifts require reliance on linear approximations
Convexity accounts for non-linear effects from larger rate movements
Duration is only valid when convexity is zero

questions.explanation: Convexity is crucial for capturing non-linear effects when rate shocks are not small.

questions.questionText: A trader seeks to hedge a position with positive duration and negative convexity using only one bond. Why will such a hedge remain incomplete?

options.text: One bond cannot hedge both duration and convexity simultaneously
Negative convexity automatically reverses duration exposure
Convexity is irrelevant for hedging fixed-income instruments
DV01 and duration are identical measures

questions.explanation: Hedging both duration and convexity requires at least two instruments; one is insufficient for matching two sensitivities.

questions.questionText: An analyst constructs a bullet portfolio with the same duration as a barbell portfolio. If the term structure is upward sloping and stable, which portfolio is expected to generate higher yield?

options.text: Neither portfolio’s yield is predictable under these conditions

questions.explanation: With an upward-sloping curve, bullets often offer higher yield for the same duration because intermediate maturities carry higher yields than short–long blends.

questions.questionText: A risk manager computes the effective convexity of a bond and obtains a large positive value. What does this imply about the bond’s price behavior under rate movements?

options.text: Price increases are smaller when yields fall
Price decreases are larger when yields rise
Price benefits more from rate declines and is cushioned during rate increases
The bond has embedded options reducing convexity

questions.explanation: Positive convexity means price rises more when rates fall and drops less when rates rise.

questions.questionText: A bank holds multiple fixed-income instruments and wishes to compute portfolio duration. Which calculation appropriately incorporates individual instrument durations?

options.text: Weighting each duration by the proportion of total portfolio value
Weighting durations by each instrument’s coupon rate

questions.explanation: Portfolio duration is a value-weighted average of individual durations.

questions.questionText: An investor holds a puttable bond whose put option is out-of-the-money. When rates increase sharply, what happens to duration?

options.text: Duration rises because the put becomes more likely to be exercised
Duration falls because the bond behaves more like a long-maturity option-free bond
Duration remains unchanged because embedded options only react to rate decreases
Duration becomes zero because the put dominates the payoff

questions.explanation: Higher rates increase the likelihood of exercising the put, reducing effective maturity and lowering duration.

questions.questionText: A trader calculates DV01 using a 1 bp shock and a 10 bp shock and notes slightly different results. What causes this discrepancy?

options.text: The bond’s price-yield relationship is perfectly linear
Convexity causes DV01 to vary slightly with the size of the rate shock
DV01 is only valid for zero-coupon bonds

questions.explanation: Because the price-yield curve is curved, DV01 measured with different shock sizes differs slightly due to convexity effects.

questions.questionText: An investment firm hedges a position using two bonds to neutralize both duration and convexity. Despite this, the hedge performs poorly when rates at different maturities move in opposite directions. What risk was not neutralized?
questions.explanation: Duration-plus-convexity hedges protect only against parallel shifts; twists and butterflies still cause exposures.

questions.questionText: A manager considers replacing a bullet portfolio with a barbell portfolio of equal duration. What advantage does the barbell portfolio typically provide?

options.text: Higher convexity, improving resilience under parallel shifts
Guaranteed superior performance under all rate movements
Perfect hedging against non-parallel curve shifts

questions.explanation: Barbells tend to have higher convexity, making them perform better under parallel shifts.

questions.questionText: A trader values a 10-year zero-coupon bond with a face value of USD 100 when the yield is 4% with semiannual compounding. After a 1 bp increase in yield to 4.01%, the price falls from 67.30 to 67.23. What is the bond’s DV01 per USD 100 of face value?
questions.explanation: DV01 is the dollar price change for a 1 bp move, so DV01 ≈ 67.30 − 67.23 = 0.07 ≈ 0.066 per USD 100 face.

questions.questionText: For the same 10-year zero-coupon bond (price ≈ 67.30, DV01 ≈ 0.066 per USD 100), a risk manager wants its effective duration in years. Yields are measured as decimals, and the 1 bp shock is 0.0001. What is the effective duration?
questions.explanation: Effective duration D ≈ DV01 / (P × 0.0001) ≈ 0.066 / (67.30 × 0.0001) ≈ 9.8 years.

questions.questionText: The same 10-year zero-coupon bond has prices 67.23 and 67.36 when the yield is shifted up and down by 1 bp from 4%, with the original price at 67.30. Using ∆y = 0.0001, what is the effective convexity?

A 5-year bond with a 4% annual coupon (paid semiannually) and USD 100 face value is priced off a flat 5% yield curve. Its price is approximately 95.62, and after a 1 bp yield increase to 5.01% the price falls to 95.58. What is the DV01 per USD 100 face value?
questions.explanation: DV01 ≈ 95.62 − 95.58 ≈ 0.04, more precisely about 0.0426 per USD 100 face.

questions.questionText: For the same 5-year 4% bond (price ≈ 95.62, DV01 ≈ 0.0426 per USD 100), a portfolio manager wants its effective duration. With a 1 bp yield shock (0.0001), what is the effective duration in years?
A bank holds USD 20 million notional of the 5-year 4% bond whose DV01 is 0.0426 per USD 100. What is the approximate DV01 of the bank’s total position?
questions.explanation: Per USD 1 million, DV01 ≈ 0.0426 × 10,000 ≈ 426; for USD 20 million, DV01 ≈ 426 × 20 ≈ 8,526 per bp.

questions.questionText: A 3-year bond with a 4% annual coupon (semiannual) and USD 100 face value is priced from a flat 5% curve. Its price is 97.25, and after a 5 bp increase in yield to 5.05% and a 5 bp decrease to 4.95%, its prices are 97.11 and 97.38, respectively. What is its effective duration?
Using the same 3-year 4% bond (P0 = 97.25, P+ = 97.11, P− = 97.38) and a 5 bp yield shock, a risk analyst wants its effective convexity. What is the approximate convexity?

A 2-year bond with a 3% annual coupon (semiannual) and USD 100 face is priced using a flat 2.5% yield curve and has a price of approximately 100.97. Its effective duration is estimated as 1.93 years. What is the DV01 per USD 100 face value?
A 7-year bond with a 5% annual coupon (semiannual) has a price of 106.05 when the yield is 4%. Its effective duration is 5.91 years. What is the DV01 per USD 100 face value?
A portfolio manager holds USD 10 million notional of the 7-year 5% bond (DV01 ≈ 0.0627 per USD 100). What is the portfolio’s DV01?
questions.explanation: DV01 per USD 1 million ≈ 0.0627 × 10,000 ≈ 627; for USD 10 million, DV01 ≈ 627 × 10 ≈ 6,270 per bp (rounded ≈ 6,267).

questions.questionText: The 7-year 5% bond (P0 = 106.05) has effective duration 5.91 and effective convexity 41.2. If yields rise by 50 bps (0.005 in decimal), what is the approximate price change using the duration-plus-convexity approximation?

A bank’s swap book has a net DV01 of –30,000, meaning it gains USD 30,000 when rates rise by 1 bp. The bank wants to hedge with the 7-year 5% bond whose DV01 is approximately USD 627 per bp per USD 1 million. What face amount of the bond is needed to neutralize the DV01?
